chunk_text: [Page 92] Long-Term Incentive: Performance Share Program (PSP) The PSP is designed to motivate senior leadership worldwide to execute their duties in a way that not only achieves ConocoPhillips’ approved strategy but also closely aligns senior leadership with long-term stockholder interests. [Page 92] Approximately 60 of our current employees participate in the PSP. [Page 92] Grants made to NEOs in 2023 for PSP 23 are summarized in note 3 of the Summary Compensation Table on page 98. [Page 92] Performance measures and peers for all ongoing programs can be found on page 76. [Page 92] PSP 21 PERFORMANCE In 2021, the HRCC approved performance metrics for the PSP performance period running from January 2021 through December 2023. [Page 92] The PSP uses staggered three-year performance periods, with PSP 21 using two corporate performance measures: (1) relative Total Shareholder Return, which is weighted 60%; and (2) relative Financial, which is weighted 40%. [Page 92] The HRCC considered ConocoPhillips’ overall performance based on the PSP 21 performance measures set forth above, which, similar to VCIP, directly correspond to our strategic priorities and support our goal to deliver superior returns to stockholders through price cycles. [Page 92] See “Executive Overview — Executive Compensation — Strategic Alignment” on page 72 and “Process for Determining Executive Compensation — Corporate Performance Criteria” beginning on page 81. [Page 92] HRCC REVIEW PROCESS In determining award payouts under PSP 21, the HRCC met several times with management throughout the performance period to review progress and performance against the approved metrics. [Page 92] The review with the HRCC in late January 2024 focused on the detailed final results for each performance metric. [Page 92] The final review in mid-February 2024 focused on a summary of the results for each performance metric and deliberation and determination of the final payout by the HRCC. [Page 92] This process allows the HRCC to consider results in one meeting and make informed payout decisions in a separate meeting. [Page 92] 2021 – 2023 RESULTS TSR – 60% weighting Three-year TSR of 46% resulted in a relative ranking of 4th in TSR, putting us in the 71st percentile (160% payout per the matrix) in TSR compared to our performance peer group based over the three-year performance period on the 20-day average methodology, outperforming the independent and integrated performance peer average and the overall peer average, including significantly outperforming the S&P 500. [Page 92] The HRCC then followed the matrix on page 84 in making its determination of the payout for this relative TSR metric. [Page 92] FINANCIAL – 40% weighting We finished 4th in Adjusted ROCE (63rd percentile) relative to our performance peers over the three-year performance period (137% payout per the matrix). [Page 92] The HRCC followed the matrix on page 84 in making its determination of the payout for the relative Financial metric. [Page 92] The HRCC believes ConocoPhillips is executing the right strategy and recognizes the leadership and commitment our executives demonstrated during the performance period. [Page 92] The HRCC believes that a 151% formulaic payout reflects ConocoPhillips’ overall strong performance during the 2021-2023 performance period. [Page 92] 92 ConocoPhillips Compensation Discussion and Analysis [Page 93] The HRCC believes there is strong alignment between stockholder interests and executive compensation. [Page 93] The following table describes the details the HRCC considered as quantitative performance measures and summarizes the payout decisions for PSP 21: Metric Category Category Weighting Metric PSP Results and Performance Summary Payout Weighted Payout TSR 60% Total Shareholder Return (relative to peers) 4th in peer group (71st percentile; 160% payout per matrix) for 2021- 2023 based on 20-day average methodology 160% 96% Financial(1) 40% Adjusted ROCE (relative to peers) 4th in peer group (63rd percentile; 137% payout per matrix) 137% 55% Total Payout 151% (1) Adjustments for material, nonrecurring special items (e.g., gains on dispositions, impairments) are made to company results to determine Adjusted ROCE, and we also use disclosed material adjustments made by peers when measuring relative to peer performance. [Page 93] Adjusted earnings (loss) in the absolute Adjusted ROCE calculations is a non-GAAP financial measure. [Page 93] A reconciliation to GAAP and a discussion of the usefulness and purpose of adjusted earnings (loss) can be found in Appendix A. [Page 93] Long-Term Incentive: Executive Restricted Stock Unit Program All 2023 awards under the Executive Restricted Stock Unit Program were made at target. [Page 93] Approximately 60 of our current employees participate in this program. [Page 93] The 2023 grants to NEOs can be found in note 3 of the Summary Compensation Table on page 98. [Page 93] Other Executive Compensation and Benefits Other Compensation and Personal Benefits In addition to our four primary compensation components, we provide our NEOs a limited number of benefits as described below. [Page 93] Some benefits, such as executive life insurance coverage and nonqualified benefit plans, are provided for competitive reasons. [Page 93] Other benefits are designed primarily to promote a healthy work/life balance, to provide opportunities for developing business relationships, and to personalize our social responsibility programs. [Page 93] Comprehensive Security Program — Because our executives face personal safety risks in their roles as representatives of a global E&P company, our Board has adopted a comprehensive security program for our executives. [Page 93] Personal Entertainment — ConocoPhillips executives participate in community, university, and philanthropic organizations at the request of the company. [Page 93] We also purchase tickets to various cultural, charitable, civic, entertainment, and sporting events for business development and relationship-building purposes, as well as to maintain our involvement in communities where we operate. [Page 93] Occasionally, our employees, including our executives, make personal use of tickets that would not otherwise be used for business purposes. [Page 93] We believe these tickets offer an opportunity to expand our networks at a very low or no incremental cost to ConocoPhillips. [Page 93] Tax Gross-Ups — Certain of the personal benefits received by our executives are deemed by the Internal Revenue Service to be taxable income to the individual. [Page 93] When we determine that such income is incurred for purposes more properly characterized as company business than personal benefit, we provide additional payments to the executive to reimburse the cost of including the item in the executive’s taxable income. [Page 93] Most often, these tax gross-up payments are provided for travel by a family member or other personal guest to attend a meeting or function at our request in furtherance of company business, such as Board meetings, company-sponsored events, and industry and association meetings where spouses or other guests are expected to attend. [Page 93] 93 2024 Proxy Statement Compensation Discussion and Analysis [Page 94] Tax and Financial Planning Services — We provide our NEOs with certain tax, estate, and financial planning services up to $15,000 plus any travel–related expenses incurred by the advisor when meeting with an executive. [Page 94] The benefit is provided while serving as an executive and for up to six months following retirement from the company. [Page 94] We do not provide a tax gross-up for these benefits. [Page 94] Executive Life Insurance — We provide life insurance policies and death benefits for all of our U.S.-based salaried employees (at no cost to the employee) with a face value approximately equal to the employee’s annual salary. [Page 94] For each of our executives under the ConocoPhillips benefits program, we maintain an additional life insurance policy (at no cost to the executive) with a value approximately equal to the executive’s annual salary. [Page 94] In addition to these two plans, we also provide our executives the option of purchasing group variable universal life insurance or term life insurance in an amount up to eight times their respective annual salaries. [Page 94] We believe that making additional insurance available for purchase at their own expense is valued by our executives and can be provided at no cost to ConocoPhillips. [Page 94] Defined Contribution Plans — In addition to the ConocoPhillips Savings Plan, which is our qualified defined contribution plan for U.S.-based employees, we maintain the nonqualified defined contribution plans listed below for our executives. [Page 94] These plans allow deferred amounts to grow tax-free until distributed, while enabling ConocoPhillips to use the money for the duration of the deferral period for general corporate purposes. [Page 94] These types of plans are common among our competitors, and we believe the lack of such plans would put ConocoPhillips at a disadvantage in attracting and retaining talented executives. [Page 94] • Voluntary Deferred Compensation Plans — The purpose of our voluntary nonqualified deferred compensation plans is to allow executives to defer a portion of their salary and incentive compensation so that such amounts are not immediately taxable. [Page 94] • Make-Up Plans — The purpose of our nonqualified defined contribution make-up plans is to provide benefits that an executive would otherwise lose due to limitations imposed by the Internal Revenue Code on high-income participants in qualified plans. [Page 94] Additional information on these plans is provided under Nonqualified Deferred Compensation beginning on page 107. [Page 94] Defined Benefit Plans — In addition to the ConocoPhillips Retirement Plan, which is our qualified defined benefit plan for U.S.-based employees, we also maintain nonqualified defined benefit plans for our executives. [Page 94] The primary purpose of these plans is to provide benefits that an executive would otherwise lose due to limitations imposed by the Internal Revenue Code on high-income participants in qualified plans. [Page 94] The U.S. [Page 94] nonqualified defined benefit plan available to our NEOs is the Key Employee Supplemental Retirement Plan (“KESRP”). [Page 94] This type of plan is common among our competitors and we believe the lack of such a plan would put ConocoPhillips at a disadvantage in attracting and retaining talented executives. [Page 94] Effective January 1, 2019, the ConocoPhillips Retirement Plan was closed to new hires and rehires who will instead receive an enhanced benefit under the ConocoPhillips Savings Plan and a related make-up plan. [Page 94] Additional information on the KESRP is provided under Pension Benefits beginning on page 105. [Page 94] Severance Plans and Changes in Control We maintain plans to address severance of our executives in certain circumstances as described under Executive Severance and Changes in Control beginning on page 109. [Page 94] Plans of this nature are common within the industry. [Page 94] Our plans are designed to aid ConocoPhillips in attracting and retaining executives. [Page 94] Under each of our severance and change in control severance plans, the executive must terminate from service with ConocoPhillips to receive severance pay. [Page 94] Excise tax gross-up benefits are not available under these plans. [Page 94] Vesting of awards under the PSP, Executive Restricted Stock Unit Program, and Stock Option Program that are assumed by an acquirer will accelerate only upon the occurrence of both a change in control event and a qualifying termination of employment of the employee (usually called a “double trigger”). [Page 94] Broadly Available Plans Our NEOs are eligible to participate in the same basic benefits package as our other U.S. [Page 94] salaried employees. [Page 94] This includes expatriate benefits; relocation services; medical, dental, vision, life, and accident plans; health savings accounts; and flexible spending arrangements for health care and dependent care expenses. [Page 94] 94 ConocoPhillips Compensation Discussion and Analysis [Page 95] Executive Compensation Governance Alignment of Interests — Stock Ownership and Holding Requirements We place a premium on aligning the interests of our executives with those of our stockholders. [Page 95] All executives are subject to stock ownership guidelines, with an eight times base salary guideline for the CEO (increased from six times effective in 2023) and three to four times base salary guideline for other NEOs. [Page 95] Executives have five years from the date they become subject to the Stock Ownership Guidelines to comply. [Page 95] Holdings counted toward the guidelines include: (1) shares of stock owned individually, jointly, or in trusts controlled by the employee; (2) restricted stock and restricted stock units; (3) shares owned in qualified savings or stock ownership plans, whether vested or not; and (4) stock or units in nonqualified deferred compensation plans, whether vested or not. [Page 95] Holdings not counted toward the guidelines include PSP target units and unexercised stock options. [Page 95] Employees subject to the guidelines who have not reached the required level of stock ownership are expected to hold shares received upon vesting or earn-out of restricted stock, restricted stock units (net of shares for taxes), and shares received upon exercise of stock options (net of shares tendered or withheld for payment of exercise price and shares for taxes), so they meet their requirement in a timely manner. [Page 95] The multiple of equity held by each of our NEOs currently exceeds our established guidelines. [Page 95] Clawback Policy The HRCC has approved a Clawback Policy providing that ConocoPhillips will recoup any incentive compensation (cash or equity) paid or payable to any executive to the extent such recoupment is required or contemplated by the provisions of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (the “Dodd-Frank Act”), the Sarbanes- Oxley Act, or any other applicable law or listing standards. [Page 95] To comply with NYSE listing standards and final SEC rules under the Dodd-Frank Act, the HRCC adopted a restated Clawback Policy effective October 2, 2023. [Page 95] The Clawback Policy requires the Board to recoup incentive compensation (cash or equity) paid in the event of certain business circumstances, including a financial restatement. [Page 95] The policy operates in addition to provisions already contained in our award documents for the PSP, the Executive Restricted Stock Unit Program, the Stock Option Program, and other compensation programs using company equity. [Page 95] Those documents permit the HRCC or other granting committee to suspend rights to exercise, refuse to honor the exercise of awards already requested, or cancel awards granted if an executive engages in any activity we determine is detrimental to ConocoPhillips, including acts of misconduct (such as embezzlement, fraud, theft, or disclosure of confidential information) or other acts that harm our business, reputation, or employees, as well as misconduct that results in ConocoPhillips having to prepare an accounting restatement. [Page 95] To date, no NEOs have been subject to any clawbacks. [Page 95] Anti-Pledging and Anti-Hedging Pursuant to our insider trading policy, ConocoPhillips directors, officers and all other employees are prohibited from pledging company stock, holding company stock in a margin account, or entering into hedging transactions, including the use of financial instruments such as prepaid variable forwards, equity swaps, collars, and exchange funds. [Page 95] This policy, together with the Stock Ownership Guidelines discussed above, helps ensure that our NEOs and other Senior Officers remain subject to the risks, as well as the rewards, of stock ownership. [Page 95] Equity Grant Practices When the HRCC awards Performance Share Units, Executive Restricted Stock Units, or other equity grants to the NEOs, the fair market value of the units or the exercise price of the options or other equity is determined based on an average of the stock’s high and low prices on the date of grant (or the preceding business day, if the markets are closed on the date of grant). [Page 95] For purposes of granting such awards, we use an average of the closing prices on the 10 trading days preceding the date of grant. [Page 95] Grants of Performance Share Units and Executive Restricted Stock Units are generally made at the HRCC’s February meeting (the date of which is determined at least a year in advance) or, in the case of new hires, on the date of commencement of employment or the date of HRCC approval, whichever is later. [Page 95] 95 2024 Proxy Statement Compensation Discussion and Analysis [Page 96] Statutory and Regulatory Considerations In designing, implementing, and determining compensation under our compensation programs, we act in accordance with our compensation philosophy and believe that attracting, retaining, and motivating our employees with compensation programs that support long-term value creation is in the best interests of our stockholders. [Page 96] However, we also take into account the various tax, accounting, and disclosure rules associated with various forms of compensation. [Page 96] We have reviewed and considered the deductibility of executive compensation under Section 162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code and designed deferred compensation programs with the intent that they comply with or are exempt from Section 409A of the Internal Revenue Code. [Page 96] We generally seek to preserve tax deductions for executive compensation where possible and commensurate with our practice of aligning pay with performance. [Page 96] Nonetheless, ConocoPhillips has awarded compensation that is not fully tax deductible when the HRCC believes that doing so is in the best interest of our stockholders, and ConocoPhillips reserves the right to do so in the future. [Page 96] 96 ConocoPhillips Compensation Discussion and Analysis

summarization.introduction: This text discusses ConocoPhillips' Long-Term Incentive Performance Share Program (PSP) designed to align senior leadership's actions with the company's strategy and stockholder interests, as well as other executive compensation and benefit plans. It details the structure, review process, and results of PSP 21, along with other elements of executive compensation such as restricted stock units, various benefits, stock ownership guidelines, and clawback policies.
summarization.main_points: The Performance Share Program (PSP) motivates senior leadership through performance-based metrics like relative Total Shareholder Return (TSR) and Adjusted ROCE. PSP 21, covering 2021-2023, resulted in a 151% formulaic payout, reflecting strong performance in TSR and Adjusted ROCE compared to peer companies. The Human Resources and Compensation Committee (HRCC) plays a crucial role in reviewing progress, determining payouts, and ensuring alignment with stockholder interests. ConocoPhillips also offers restricted stock unit programs, executive benefits, and maintains a clawback policy, stock ownership guidelines, and anti-hedging policies to further align executive and stockholder interests.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips' executive compensation strategy prioritizes long-term value creation and alignment with stockholder interests through a combination of performance-based incentives, benefits, and governance policies. The HRCC's oversight ensures that compensation decisions are aligned with the company's strategic objectives and regulatory requirements.

qa_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the Performance Share Program (PSP)?
qa_pairs.answer: The PSP is designed to motivate senior leadership to execute their duties in a way that achieves ConocoPhillips’ approved strategy and aligns senior leadership with long-term stockholder interests.

qa_pairs.question: How many employees participate in the PSP?
qa_pairs.answer: Approximately 60 of ConocoPhillips' current employees participate in the PSP.

qa_pairs.question: What were the two corporate performance measures used in PSP 21?
qa_pairs.answer: The two corporate performance measures used in PSP 21 were relative Total Shareholder Return (60% weighting) and relative Financial (40% weighting).

qa_pairs.question: What was the HRCC's determination of the final payout for PSP 21?
qa_pairs.answer: The HRCC determined that a 151% formulaic payout reflects ConocoPhillips’ overall strong performance during the 2021-2023 performance period.

qa_pairs.question: What are executives expected to do if they have not reached the required level of stock ownership?
qa_pairs.answer: Employees subject to stock ownership guidelines who have not reached the required level of stock ownership are expected to hold shares received upon vesting or earn-out of restricted stock, restricted stock units (net of shares for taxes), and shares received upon exercise of stock options (net of shares tendered or withheld for payment of exercise price and shares for taxes), so they meet their requirement in a timely manner.

qa_pairs.question: What does ConocoPhillips' Clawback Policy entail?
qa_pairs.answer: The Clawback Policy provides that ConocoPhillips will recoup any incentive compensation (cash or equity) paid or payable to any executive to the extent such recoupment is required or contemplated by the provisions of the Dodd-Frank Act, the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, or any other applicable law or listing standards, including a financial restatement.

qa_pairs.question: Are executives allowed to pledge company stock?
qa_pairs.answer: No, pursuant to ConocoPhillips' insider trading policy, directors, officers and all other employees are prohibited from pledging company stock, holding company stock in a margin account, or entering into hedging transactions.

qa_pairs.question: How is the fair market value of equity grants determined?
qa_pairs.answer: The fair market value of the units or the exercise price of the options or other equity is determined based on an average of the stock’s high and low prices on the date of grant (or the preceding business day, if the markets are closed on the date of grant). For purposes of granting such awards, ConocoPhillips uses an average of the closing prices on the 10 trading days preceding the date of grant.

qa_pairs.question: What tax considerations does ConocoPhillips take into account in designing compensation programs?
qa_pairs.answer: ConocoPhillips takes into account the various tax, accounting, and disclosure rules associated with various forms of compensation, and has reviewed and considered the deductibility of executive compensation under Section 162(m) and designed deferred compensation programs with the intent that they comply with or are exempt from Section 409A of the Internal Revenue Code.

summarization.introduction: This document discusses the executive compensation arrangements for ConocoPhillips' Named Executive Officers (NEOs) in 2023, including various compensation and benefit plans. It details different elements such as final average pay, service credit, personal use of company aircraft, matching gift programs, and incentives.
summarization.main_points: The compensation packages for NEOs include a variety of elements beyond base salary, such as pension plans (for certain executives like Lance, Bullock, and Olds), medical, dental, vision, life, and accident plans, disability coverage, health savings and flexible spending accounts. Additional benefits include personal and business use of company aircraft, participation in a matching gift program, and other perks like tax and financial planning services, expatriate benefits, and executive group life insurance. The compensation also covers matching contributions under tax-qualified savings plans and company contributions to non-qualified defined contribution plans. Incentive compensation includes VCIP and PSP awards, which are subject to performance criteria and can be voluntarily deferred. The HRCC sets targets and grants awards, with payouts ranging from zero to 200 percent based on performance.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips provides its executives with a comprehensive compensation and benefits package that includes a mix of base pay, benefits, and performance-based incentives. These arrangements are designed to align executive interests with the company's performance and long-term goals.

qa_pairs.question: What factors contribute to the benefit accrual in ConocoPhillips' executive compensation?
qa_pairs.answer: Years of service credited and increases to compensation are factors in the benefit accrual.

qa_pairs.question: Which NEOs participate in a final average earnings title of ConocoPhillips' U.S. pension plans?
qa_pairs.answer: Messrs. Lance, Bullock, and Olds are the only NEOs who participate in a final average earnings title of ConocoPhillips’ U.S. pension plans.

qa_pairs.question: What benefits are excluded from the compensation discussion because they are generally available to U.S.-based salaried employees?
qa_pairs.answer: Medical, dental, vision, life, and accident plans, disability, and health savings and flexible spending account arrangements are excluded.

qa_pairs.question: What does the 'All Other Compensation' category include?
qa_pairs.answer: The 'All Other Compensation' category includes personal use of company aircraft, business-related use of company aircraft, matching gift program, other perquisites and personal benefits, tax and financial planning, expatriate benefits, executive group life insurance premiums, tax reimbursement gross-up, matching contributions under the tax-qualified savings plans, and company contributions to non-qualified defined contribution plans.

qa_pairs.question: Why is Mr. Lance required to fly on company aircraft?
qa_pairs.answer: ConocoPhillips’ Comprehensive Security Program requires that the CEO, Mr. Lance, fly on company aircraft unless the Global Security Department determines that other arrangements represent an acceptable risk.

qa_pairs.question: What is the maximum matching gift amount for executives under the Matching Gift Program?
qa_pairs.answer: For executives, the program matches up to $10,000 with regard to each program year.

qa_pairs.question: What did the amounts in the 'Other' column represent for NEOs?
qa_pairs.answer: The amounts represent other perquisites and personal benefits including the cost of presentations made to employees and their spouses at Company meetings or events, reimbursements for the cost of spousal and other guests attendance at such meetings or events, and the aggregate incremental cost of any other personal benefits or perquisites not integrally and directly related to the performance of the executive’s duties arising from such presentations, meetings, or events, primarily food, drink and transportation. Also includes any aggregate incremental cost of enhanced home security, transportation security, and other protection services provided under our Comprehensive Security Program. Additionally, for Mr. Olds, it included the company's cost of a house and leased automobile in Midland, Texas.

qa_pairs.question: What was the maximum benefit provided for professional advice related to tax, estate and financial planning in 2023?
qa_pairs.answer: The maximum benefit in 2023 was $15,000 plus any travel-related expenses incurred by the advisor when meeting with an executive. No tax gross-up is provided for these costs.

qa_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the Outstanding Equity Awards at Fiscal Year-End table?
qa_pairs.answer: The Outstanding Equity Awards at Fiscal Year-End table is used to show equity awards measured in ConocoPhillips stock held by the NEOs.

qa_pairs.question: What market value per share was used for the Outstanding Equity Awards at Fiscal Year-End table?
qa_pairs.answer: A market value of $116.07 per share was used, which was the closing stock price of the company’s common stock on December 29, 2023.

qa_pairs.question: When do stock awards under the Executive Restricted Stock Unit Program restrictions lapse?
qa_pairs.answer: Under the Executive Restricted Stock Unit Program, stock awards have restrictions on transferability, which lapse three years from the anniversary of the grant date.

qa_pairs.question: What happens to dividend equivalents on RSUs under the Executive Restricted Stock Unit Program?
qa_pairs.answer: Dividend equivalents, if any, on RSUs held under the Executive Restricted Stock Unit Program are reinvested in additional RSUs and are paid at the same time and the same rate as dividends on common stock.

qa_pairs.question: What forms do stock awards under the PSP take?
qa_pairs.answer: Under the PSP, stock awards are made in the form of restricted stock units (RSUs) or restricted stock.

qa_pairs.question: What is the settlement type for awards made for performance periods beginning after 2012?
qa_pairs.answer: For performance periods beginning after 2012, restrictions will lapse three years after the grant, and awards will be settled in cash.

[Page 105] Pension Benefits Our defined benefit pension plan for U.S. [Page 105] based employees is the ConocoPhillips Retirement Plan (“CPRP”). [Page 105] The CPRP is intended to be tax-qualified under section 401(a) of the Internal Revenue Code. [Page 105] Our NEOs also participate in the nonqualified ConocoPhillips Key Employee Supplemental Retirement Plan (“KESRP”). [Page 105] The CPRP consists of multiple titles with different terms, each corresponding to a different pension formula. [Page 105] NEOs are only eligible to participate in one title at any time but may have frozen benefits under one or more other titles. [Page 105] Benefits are identified by title in the table below, and all NEOs are vested in their benefits under the CPRP. [Page 105] Each title allows for payment in the form of several annuity types or a single lump sum, but all of the options are considered actuarially equivalent. [Page 105] Effective January 1, 2019, the CPRP was closed to additional benefit accrual for new hires and rehires who instead are eligible for an enhanced benefit under the ConocoPhillips Savings Plan and a related make-up plan. [Page 105] Normal retirement for all of the CPRP titles is defined as the later of age 65 or the employment termination date, but participants in Title II may receive their vested benefits upon termination of employment at any age. [Page 105] Under Title I, early retirement can occur at age 55 with five years of service. [Page 105] Under Title IV, early retirement can occur at age 50 with ten years of service. [Page 105] Under Title I, early retirement benefits are unreduced for benefits that commence at or after age 60, but are reduced by five percent per year (prorated by month) for each year before age 60 that benefits are paid. [Page 105] Under Title IV, early retirement benefits are unreduced for benefits that commence at or after age 60, but are reduced by five percent per year (prorated by month) for each year from age 50 to age 57 that benefits are paid before age 60 and four percent per year (prorated by month) for each year from age 57 that benefits are paid before age 60. [Page 105] Messrs. [Page 105] Lance, Bullock, and Olds were eligible for early retirement at the end of 2023 under the terms of Title I or Title IV, as applicable. [Page 105] The annual pension benefit under Title I and Title IV is an amount payable in the form of a single life annuity beginning at normal or early retirement equal to 1.6% multiplied by the participant’s pension compensation multiplied by years of credited service, minus a Social Security benefit offset equal to 1.5% multiplied by the participant’s annual primary Social Security benefit multiplied by years of credited service. [Page 105] For Title I, pension compensation is calculated using the three highest consecutive years in the last ten years before retirement. [Page 105] For Title IV, pension compensation is calculated using the higher of the highest consecutive 36- months of compensation or the highest nonconsecutive three years of compensation. [Page 106] 106 ConocoPhillips Executive Compensation Tables Eligible pension compensation is limited to the annual maximum permitted under the Internal Revenue Code and generally includes salary and annual incentive compensation and other items (such as overtime) that are not applicable to or are not material for our NEOs. [Page 106] Under Title I, if an executive receives layoff benefits, eligible pension compensation includes annualized salary for the year of layoff, rather than actual salary, and years of credited service are increased by the layoff benefit period. [Page 106] Pension benefits under Title II are based on monthly pay and interest credits to a notional cash balance account. [Page 106] Pay credits are equal to a percentage of eligible pension compensation as described above. [Page 106] Participants whose combined age and years of service total less than 44 receive a 6% pay credit, those whose combined age and years of service total 44 through 65 receive a 7% pay credit, and those whose combined age and years of service total 66 or more receive a 9% pay credit. [Page 106] Mr. [Page 106] Macklon began participating in Title II of CPRP when he transferred to the U.S. [Page 106] payroll. [Page 106] Previously while he was on the U.K. [Page 106] payroll, he participated in the ConocoPhillips Pension Plan (the “U.K. [Page 106] Plan”). [Page 106] The U.K. [Page 106] Plan is a U.K. [Page 106] registered plan with His Majesty’s Revenue and Customs (“HMRC”). [Page 106] Mr. [Page 106] Macklon has a deferred, vested benefit under the noncontributory portion of the U.K. [Page 106] Plan. [Page 106] Under applicable provisions of the U.K. [Page 106] Plan, a member is entitled to receive full benefits upon attainment of normal pension age (60 in the case of Mr. [Page 106] Macklon) subsequent to termination. [Page 106] Early retirement may occur after reaching age 55. [Page 106] Early retirement benefits are unreduced on and after age 60, but are actuarially reduced each month before age 60 that benefits are paid. [Page 106] In general, annual pension benefits under the U.K. [Page 106] Plan are calculated as the product of 1.75% of final pensionable salary multiplied by years of credited service. [Page 106] Final pensionable salary is generally basic annual salary plus pensionable allowances earned in the 12 months before active membership in the U.K. [Page 106] Plan ends. [Page 106] The U.K. [Page 106] Plan allows participants to choose between taking a full annuity or a reduced annuity plus a lump sum allowance of up to 25 percent of the value of the benefit (capped at the greater of £268,275, or 25% of the protected lifetime allowance in effect when the allowance was prospectively eliminated in 2023). [Page 106] Both choices are actuarially equivalent. [Page 106] The KESRP is designed to replace benefits that would otherwise not be received due to certain voluntary reductions of compensation under the Key Employee Deferred Compensation Plan of ConocoPhillips (“KEDCP”) and to limitations contained in the Internal Revenue Code that apply to the CPRP. [Page 106] The KESRP determines a benefit without regard to such limits, and then reduces that benefit by the amount of benefit payable from the CPRP. [Page 106] Thus, in operation the combined benefits payable from the related plans for an eligible employee equal the benefit that would have been paid if there had been no KEDCP deferrals or limitations imposed by the Internal Revenue Code. [Page 106] For participants in Title I of the CPRP, the KESRP pension compensation is calculated using the three highest annual amounts for salary and VCIP in the last ten calendar years before retirement plus the year of retirement. [Page 106] Applicable pension compensation for participants in Title II and Title IV of the CPRP, is calculated on the same basis as for the CPRP. [Page 106] Benefits under the KESRP are generally paid in a single lump sum at the later of age 55 or six months after separation from service. [Page 106] When payment is made, interest at then-current six-month Treasury-bill rates will be credited on any delayed benefits. [Page 106] Distribution may also be made upon a determination of death or disability. [Page 106] Each of the NEOs who are eligible for benefits in the KESRP is vested. [Page 106] Benefits due under the KESRP are paid from ConocoPhillips’ general assets, although we also maintain grantor trusts that may be used to pay such benefits. [Page 106] The trusts and the funds held in them are assets of ConocoPhillips. [Page 106] In the event of bankruptcy or insolvency of the company, trust assets would be held for the benefit of the company’s general creditors, and participants would be unsecured general creditors. [Page 106] For participants in the U.K. [Page 106] Plan, there is a plan similar to the KESRP, known as the ConocoPhillips Unfunded Pension Plan (“U.K Unfunded Plan”), which operates on the same principles but with respect to limits imposed through HMRC on registered plans like the U.K. [Page 106] Plan. [Page 106] Mr. [Page 106] Macklon is a participant in the U.K. [Page 106] Unfunded Plan with regard to the time he worked in the U.K. [Page 106] from September 1, 2013 to December 31, 2016, at which time he transferred to the U.S. [Page 106] payroll (Mr. [Page 106] Macklon was a participant in the U.K. [Page 106] Plan prior to September 1, 2013). [Page 106] Mr. [Page 106] Macklon is vested in his benefit under the U.K. [Page 106] Unfunded Plan, and such benefit is payable when he attains 55 years of age in the form of a lump sum, or series of lump sums payable over a five- or ten-year period. [Page 109] While normal retirement age under our benefit plans is 65, early retirement provisions allow benefits at earlier ages if vesting requirements are met, as discussed in the sections of this Proxy Statement titled Pension Benefits and Nonqualified Deferred Compensation. [Page 109] For our compensation programs (VCIP, Stock Option Program, Executive RSU Program, and PSP), early retirement is generally defined to be termination at or after the age of 55 with five years of service. [Page 109] As of December 31, 2023, Messrs. [Page 109] Lance and Bullock and Ms. [Page 109] Rose had met the early retirement criteria. [Page 109] Messrs. [Page 109] Macklon and Olds, who were under the age of 55, and had not met the early retirement criteria at such date. [Page 109] In addition, specific severance arrangements for executive officers, including the NEOs, are provided under two severance plans: (1) the ConocoPhillips Executive Severance Plan (“CPESP”), which is available to a limited number of senior executives; and (2) the ConocoPhillips Key Employee Change in Control Severance Plan (“CICSP”), which is also available to a limited number of senior executives but only on or following change in control. [Page 109] These arrangements are described below. [Page 109] Executives are not entitled to participate in both plans as a result of a single event. [Page 109] For example, executives receiving benefits under the CICSP would not be entitled to benefits potentially payable under the CPESP relating to the event giving rise to benefits under the CICSP. [Page 110] 110 ConocoPhillips Executive Compensation Tables ConocoPhillips Executive Severance Plan The CPESP covers executives in salary grades generally corresponding to vice president and higher and is incorporated by reference to Exhibit 10.47 to the Annual Report of ConocoPhillips on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2021; File No. [Page 110] 001-32395. [Page 110] Under the CPESP, if ConocoPhillips terminates a plan participant other than for cause, as defined in the plan, then upon executing a general release of liability and, if requested, an agreement not to compete with ConocoPhillips, the participant will be entitled to: • A lump-sum cash payment equal to one-and-a-half or two times the sum of the employee’s base salary and current target VCIP award; • For executives actively participating in the ConocoPhillips Retirement Plan (CPRP) and ConocoPhillips Key Employee Supplemental Retirement Plan (KESRP), a lump-sum cash payment equal to the present value of the increase in pension benefits that would result from the crediting of an additional one-and-a-half or two years to the employee’s number of years of age and service under the applicable defined benefit pension formula under the plans; • A lump-sum cash payment equal to ConocoPhillips’ cost of certain welfare benefits for an additional one-and-a-half or two years; • Continued eligibility for a pro rata portion of the annual VCIP for the year of termination; and • Treatment as a layoff under our various compensation and equity programs. [Page 110] Generally, layoff treatment will allow full or partial vesting of awards previously made and continued eligibility under ongoing ConocoPhillips programs. [Page 110] Thus, Executive RSU awards would vest partially (for grants 6-12 months before the layoff) or fully (for grants more than 12 months before the layoff), and the executive would remain eligible for a pro rata proportion of awards attributable to ongoing performance periods under the PSP in which the executive had participated for at least one year. [Page 110] ConocoPhillips may amend or terminate the CPESP at any time. [Page 110] Amounts payable under the CPESP will be offset by any payments or benefits that are payable to the severed employee under any other plan, policy, or program of ConocoPhillips relating to severance, and amounts may also be reduced in the event of willful and bad faith conduct demonstrably injurious to ConocoPhillips, monetarily or otherwise, or, if required by law to be “clawed back,” such as may be the case in certain circumstances under the ConocoPhillips Clawback Policy. [Page 110] ConocoPhillips Key Employee Change in Control Severance Plan The CICSP covers executives in salary grades generally corresponding to vice president and higher and is incorporated by reference to Exhibit 10.20.1 to the Annual Report of ConocoPhillips on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2021; File No. [Page 110] 001-32395. [Page 110] Under the CICSP, if within two years after a “change in control” of ConocoPhillips, a participant is terminated by ConocoPhillips other than for cause, or by the participant for good reason (as such terms are defined in the plan), upon executing a general release of liability, the participant will be entitled to: • A lump-sum cash payment equal to two or three times the sum of the employee’s base salary and the higher of current target VCIP compensation or the previous two years’ average VCIP compensation; • For executives actively participating in the CPRP and KESRP, a lump-sum cash payment equal to the present value of the increase in pension benefits that would result from crediting an additional two or three years to the employee’s number of years of age and service under the applicable defined benefit pension formula under the plans; • A lump-sum cash payment equal to ConocoPhillips’ cost of certain welfare benefits for an additional two or three years; and • Continued eligibility for a pro rata portion of the annual VCIP compensation for the year of termination. [Page 110] Excise tax gross-up benefits are not available under the CICSP. [Page 110] Upon a change in control, awards that an acquirer assumes or substitutes will be subject to accelerated vesting only following both the change in control and a qualifying termination of employment. [Page 110] A qualifying termination of employment includes involuntary termination not-for-cause or voluntary termination for good reason. [Page 110] Participants will continue to be able to exercise stock options for their remaining terms (up to 10 years from the date of grant). [Page 111] 111 2024 Proxy Statement Executive Compensation Tables After a change in control, the CICSP may not be amended or terminated if such amendment would be adverse to the interests of any eligible employee, without the employee’s written consent. [Page 111] Amounts payable under the plan will be offset by any payments or benefits that are payable to the severed employee under any other plan, policy, or program of ConocoPhillips relating to severance, and amounts may also be reduced in the event of willful and bad faith conduct demonstrably injurious to ConocoPhillips, monetarily or otherwise, or if required by law to be “clawed back,” such as may be the case in certain circumstances under the ConocoPhillips Clawback Policy. [Page 111] Quantification of Severance Payments After separating from service each of our NEOs is expected to receive amounts earned during their period of employment unless they voluntarily resign prior to becoming retirement-eligible or are terminated for-cause. [Page 111] The following tables reflect the amount of incremental compensation payable in excess of the items listed above to each of our NEOs in the event of involuntary not-for-cause termination, termination following a change in control (“CIC”) (either involuntarily without cause or for good reason), and in the event of the death or disability of the executive. [Page 111] The amounts shown below assume that such termination was effective as of December 31, 2023, and thus include amounts earned through such time, and are estimates of the amounts that would be paid out to the executives upon their termination. [Page 111] Amounts related to Health and Welfare benefits are based on current ConocoPhillips benefit programs. [Page 111] The actual amounts to be paid out can only be determined at the time of an executive’s separation from ConocoPhillips. [Page 111] In the event of a for-cause termination, the HRCC can suspend the right to exercise, refuse to honor the exercise of awards already requested, or cancel awards granted if an NEO engages in any activity determined to be detrimental to ConocoPhillips. [Page 111] In addition, the NEO’s incentive compensation is subject to the ConocoPhillips Clawback Policy (see page 95 for more information). summarization.introduction: This text provides details on ConocoPhillips' executive compensation, focusing on deferred compensation plans and severance arrangements. It outlines the plans available to executives, including the Key Employee Deferred Compensation Plan (KEDCP), the Defined Contribution Match Plan (DCMP), the Executive Severance Plan (CPESP), and the Key Employee Change in Control Severance Plan (CICSP).
summarization.main_points: The document details how executives can invest their deferred compensation, noting the variety of notional investment options available under KEDCP and DCMP, as well as the risks associated with the trusts used to hold plan assets in the event of bankruptcy. It describes the terms of the CPESP and CICSP, specifying the conditions under which executives are entitled to severance payments, including scenarios involving termination without cause and change in control, and the types of benefits provided. Furthermore, the document includes tables illustrating the potential payouts to named executive officers (NEOs) under different termination scenarios, such as involuntary termination, termination following a change in control, death, or disability, with calculations based on their base salary, short-term incentives, and other benefits.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips provides comprehensive deferred compensation and severance plans for its executives, designed to provide financial security under various employment termination scenarios. The actual amounts paid out will be determined based on the specific circumstances at the time of termination.

qa_pairs.question: What happens to trust assets in the event of bankruptcy or insolvency of ConocoPhillips?
qa_pairs.answer: Trust assets would be held for the benefit of the company’s general creditors, and participants would be unsecured general creditors.

qa_pairs.question: How many notional investment options were available in the KEDCP and DCMP as of December 31, 2023?
qa_pairs.answer: There were a total of 82 notional investment options.

qa_pairs.question: What is the general definition of early retirement for ConocoPhillips' compensation programs?
qa_pairs.answer: Early retirement is generally defined to be termination at or after the age of 55 with five years of service.

qa_pairs.question: What are the two severance plans available for executive officers at ConocoPhillips?
qa_pairs.answer: The ConocoPhillips Executive Severance Plan (CPESP) and the ConocoPhillips Key Employee Change in Control Severance Plan (CICSP).

qa_pairs.question: What conditions must a plan participant meet to be entitled to benefits under the CPESP if ConocoPhillips terminates them?
qa_pairs.answer: Upon executing a general release of liability and, if requested, an agreement not to compete with ConocoPhillips.

qa_pairs.question: What happens to awards assumed or substituted by an acquirer under the CICSP upon a change in control?
qa_pairs.answer: Awards will be subject to accelerated vesting only following both the change in control and a qualifying termination of employment.

[Page 115] Compensation and benefits are benchmarked and set to be market-competitive in the employees’ home payroll country. [Page 115] Under rules adopted pursuant to the Dodd-Frank Act, ConocoPhillips is required to calculate and disclose the total compensation paid to its median employee, as well as the ratio of total compensation paid to the median employee as compared to the total compensation paid to the CEO. [Page 115] The paragraphs that follow describe our methodology and the resulting CEO pay ratio. [Page 115] The ratio of pay of the CEO compared to that of the median employee was approximately 101 to one in 2023. [Page 115] The annual total compensation of the CEO was $20,789,282. [Page 115] The estimated median of the annual total compensation of all ConocoPhillips employees other than the CEO, as represented by the annual total compensation of a median employee, was $205,547. [Page 115] To identify the “median employee,” we excluded employees from six countries, representing in total approximately 2.3 percent, or 233 employees worldwide. [Page 115] Payroll Country Excluded Number of Employees Excluded Malaysia 86 China 81 Singapore 31 Qatar 24 Libya 9 Japan 2 For the remaining employees, we used a consistently applied compensation measure that management believes reasonably reflects the annual compensation of employees and includes elements of compensation distributed widely among employees. [Page 125] Stockholder Proposals We expect Items 4 – 5 to be presented by stockholders at the Annual Meeting. [Page 125] Item 4: Stockholder Proposal — Simple Majority Vote Kenneth Steiner, 14 Stoner Ave., 2M, Great Neck, NY 11021, has notified ConocoPhillips that he intends to present the following proposal at the Annual Meeting. [Page 125] Mr. [Page 125] Steiner has indicated that he holds the requisite number of shares of ConocoPhillips common stock in accordance with Rule 14a-8 requirements. [Page 125] What am I Voting On? [Page 125] Stockholders are being asked to vote on the following resolution: Proposal 4 – Simple Majority Vote Shareholders request that our board take each step necessary so that each voting requirement in our charter and bylaws (that is explicit or implicit due to default to state law) that calls for a greater than simple majority vote be replaced by a requirement for a majority of the votes cast for and against applicable proposals, or a simple majority in compliance with applicable laws. [Page 125] If necessary this means the closest standard to a majority of the votes cast for and against such proposals consistent with applicable laws. [Page 125] This includes making the necessary changes in plain English. [Page 125] Shareholders are willing to pay a premium for shares of companies that have excellent corporate governance. [Page 125] Supermajority voting requirements have been found to be one of 6 entrenching mechanisms that are negatively related to company performance according to “What Matters in Corporate Governance” by Lucien Bebchuck, Alma Cohen and Allen Ferrell of the Harvard Law School. [Page 125] Supermajority requirements are used to block initiatives supported by most shareowners but opposed by a status quo management. [Page 125] These votes would have been higher than 74% to 88% if more shareholders had access to independent proxy voting advice. [Page 125] This proposal topic also received overwhelming 98%-support each at the 2023 annual meetings of American Airlines (AAL) and The Carlyle Group (CG). [Page 125] This proposal topic won 99% ConocoPhillips support as a shareholder proposal at the 2021 annual meeting. [Page 125] The next step was to get binding shareholder approval as a Board of Directors proposal which required 80% approval from every last share of ConocoPhillips stock. [Page 125] The outcome was a greatly disappointing narrow failure as the BOD proposal received “only” 79% approval at the 2022 COP annual meeting. [Page 125] 2024 Proxy Statement 125 [Page 126] If ConocoPhillips Lead Director Robert Niblock had made a small effort to get an extra 1% shareholder vote this proposal topic would have been approved in 2022. [Page 126] This narrow failure is evidence that Mr. [Page 126] Niblock does not give priority to the best interests of shareholders and should thus be replaced as Lead Director. [Page 126] It will now take at least until 2025 to adopt this proposal topic, with its 99% ConocoPhillips shareholder approval, that could have been easily adopted in 2022. [Page 126] Please vote yes: Simple Majority Vote – Proposal 4 What vote is required to approve this proposal? [Page 126] WHAT DOES THE BOARD RECOMMEND? [Page 126] Our Certificate of Incorporation and By-Laws impose heightened voting requirements for a number of core governance items, including “supermajority voting requirements” to amend sections of such documents. [Page 126] The Board believes that there are advantages and disadvantages of maintaining the current voting requirements, and there are also advantages and disadvantages to eliminating them. [Page 126] Accordingly, the Board will support the stockholder proposal and, provided there is sufficient stockholder support, take steps to implement the proposal in the future. [Page 127] NLPC has indicated that it holds the requisite number of shares of ConocoPhillips common stock in accordance with Rule 14a-8 requirements. [Page 127] What am I Voting On? [Page 127] Stockholders are being asked to vote on the following resolution: Whereas: The “scientific consensus”1 2 claims anthropogenically-driven climate change will result in catastrophic impacts to the environment, to the planet, and to humans. [Page 127] However, research increasingly shows worst-case scenarios are unlikely, and the potential consequences of carbon dioxide emissions (aka “plant food”) have been greatly overstated.3 For example: • Corporate climate policy is often guided by the Paris Agreement, which is heavily informed by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.4 These targets are neither legally binding nor legitimized by scientific evidence. [Page 127] • The IPCC’s most extreme scenario unrealistically assumes a return to a previous era of unrestricted fossil fuel usage and heavy reliance on coal power.5 This extreme scenario is unlikely now that most nations have climate policies in place.6 • Regarding catastrophic scenarios that are highly unlikely but are treated as the expectation, “the media then often amplifies this message, sometimes without communicating the nuances. [Page 127] This results in further confusion regarding probable emissions outcomes, because many climate researchers are not familiar with the details of these scenarios in the energy-modeling literature.”7 • These apocalyptic predictions have been repeatedly proven false.8 Climate models used to predict future events “may be overly sensitive to carbon dioxide increases and therefore project future warming that is unrealistically high.”9 • When given historical data, climate models project impossibly high temperatures that are inconsistent with fossil evidence—yet they’re still used by the IPCC. [Page 127] • Hydrocarbons are reliable and cost-efficient. [Page 127] Renewable energy will not replace hydrocarbons in the near future, if ever.10 ConocoPhillips Company’s (“ConocoPhillips” or the “Company”) competitors are betting big on continued demand for oil and gas.11 1 https://www.mdpi.com/2225-1154/11/11/215 2 https://nypost.com/2023/08/09/climate-scientist-admits-the-overwhelming-consensus-is-manufactured/ 3 https://judithcurry.com/2023/03/28/uns-climate-panic-is-more-politics-than-science/ 4 https://www.ipcc.ch/sr15/faq/faq-chapter-1 5 https://sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140988317301226 6 https://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-the-high-emissions-rcp8-5-global-warming-scenario/ 7 https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-00177-3 8 https://www.aei.org/carpe-diem/18-spectacularly-wrong-predictions-were-made-around-the-time-of-the-first-earth-day-in-1970-expect- more-this-year/ 9 https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2020/04/200430113003.htm 10 https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/nov/27/us-oil-gas-record-fossil-fuels-cop28-united-nations 11 https://www.wsj.com/articles/chevron-bets-on-peak-green-energy-99e72109 2024 Proxy Statement 127

It explains the issuance and vesting of various RSUs to employees and executives, including details regarding dividend equivalents and transfer restrictions. Proposal 4, submitted by Kenneth Steiner, requests the adoption of a simple majority vote requirement in ConocoPhillips' charter and bylaws, arguing that supermajority voting requirements are detrimental to company performance. The Board of Directors supports this proposal. Proposal 5, submitted by the National Legal and Policy Center (NLPC), questions the validity of climate change predictions and asks ConocoPhillips to revisit pay incentives for GHG emission reductions.

chunk_text: [Page 128] Supporting Statement: Despite the evidence that climate alarmism is overstated, ConocoPhillips’s executive pay program incorporates unnecessary incentives to assumed combat climate change. [Page 128] • According to the Company’s 2023 Proxy Statement, the Human Resources and Compensation Committee set a Variable Cash Incentive Program target of 14 percent of total compensation for the CEO and 16 percent for other Named Executive Officers.12 • “Strategic and ESG Milestones” are one of the five metrics used to determine VCIP for NEOs. [Page 128] These milestones include: - “Demonstrated meaningful progress toward our Paris-aligned climate risk framework.” - “Progressed our long-term strategy by establishing new methane and flaring targets, executing emission reduction projects, and progressing CCS business development opportunities.” These VCIP metrics are unscientific and create a breach of fiduciary duty. [Page 128] ConocoPhillips is an oil and gas company and should focus on what it does best. [Page 128] The company cannot afford to be left behind because of misguided executive pay incentives. [Page 128] Resolved: Shareholders of ConocoPhillips request the Board of Directors’ Human Resources and Compensation Committee to revisit its incentive guidelines for executive pay, to emphasize legitimate fiduciary goals and consider eliminating greenhouse gas reduction targets and other scientifically dubious goals from compensation inducements. [Page 128] What vote is required to approve this proposal? [Page 128] Approval of this proposal requires the affirmative vote of a majority of the shares present in person or represented by proxy at the Annual Meeting and entitled to vote on the proposal. [Page 128] WHAT DOES THE BOARD RECOMMEND? [Page 128] The Board recommends you vote AGAINST this proposal for the following reasons: The Board has carefully considered the recommendations set forth in the proposal and we believe the changes suggested are not in the best interest of ConocoPhillips or our stockholders for the following reasons: Our executive compensation is aligned with our company strategy and with the long-term interests of our stockholders. [Page 128] ConocoPhillips continues to be guided by our value proposition of superior returns to stockholders through price cycles while executing against our Triple Mandate, which sets out three objectives to align our actions with the underlying realities of our business and demonstrates our commitment to create long-term value for our stockholders. [Page 128] Our Triple Mandate includes reliably and responsibly delivering oil and gas production to meet energy transition pathway demand, delivering returns on and of capital for our stockholders, and remaining focused on achieving our net-zero operational emissions ambition. [Page 128] Consistent with our philosophy of aligning our executive compensation programs with company strategy and with the long-term interests of our stockholders, our executive compensation programs and metrics remain aligned with our value proposition and Triple Mandate (see page 72). [Page 128] An overwhelming majority of our stockholders have expressed a desire for us to link compensation with our climate commitments. [Page 128] We regularly meet with stockholders on a variety of topics, including our executive compensation programs. [Page 128] In recent years, during these engagements, an overwhelming majority of stockholders have sought to confirm how we link progress on our climate commitments to our executive compensation programs. [Page 128] Recently, ConocoPhillips created a separately weighted measure (10 percent) for “Energy Transition Milestones,” for our short-term incentive program (see page 82), and almost all of our stockholders supported our modified compensation program. [Page 128] For more information on our stockholder engagement, see “Stockholder Engagement and Board Responsiveness” beginning on page 45 and “2023 Say on Pay Vote Result, Stockholder Engagement, and Board Responsiveness” beginning on page 69. [Page 128] AGAINST For the foregoing reasons, the Board recommends you vote AGAINST this stockholder proposal. [Page 128] 12 https://static.conocophillips.com/files/resources/conocophillips-2023-proxy.pdf 128 ConocoPhillips Item 5: Stockholder Proposal — Revisit Pay Incentives for GHG Emission Reductions [Page 129] Submission of Future Stockholder Proposals and Nominations Rule 14a-8 Stockholder Proposals Under SEC rules, if you want us to include a proposal in our proxy statement for the 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders, our Corporate Secretary must receive the proposal by December 2, 2024. [Page 129] Any such proposal should comply with the requirements of Rule 14a-8 promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act. [Page 129] Proxy Access Nominations Under our proxy access By-Law, a stockholder or a group of up to 20 stockholders, owning at least 3 percent of our stock continuously for at least three years and complying with the other requirements set forth in the By-Laws, may nominate up to two individuals (or 20 percent of the Board, if greater) for election as a director at an annual meeting and have those nominees included in our proxy statement. [Page 129] Any proxy access nomination notice for our 2025 proxy statement must be delivered to the Corporate Secretary between November 2, 2024, and December 2, 2024. [Page 129] Other Proposals/Nominations Under the Advance Notice By-Law Under our By-Laws and as SEC rules permit, stockholders must follow certain procedures to nominate a person for election as a director (other than proxy access nominations) at an annual or special meeting or to introduce an item of business at an annual meeting. [Page 129] These procedures require proposing stockholders to submit the proposed nominee or item of business by delivering a notice to the Corporate Secretary. [Page 129] Assuming our 2024 Annual Meeting convenes as currently scheduled, we must receive notices for the 2025 Annual Meeting between January 14, 2025, and February 13, 2025. [Page 129] In addition to satisfying the foregoing requirements under ConocoPhillips’ By-Laws, to comply with the universal proxy rules, stockholders who intend to solicit proxies in support of director nominees for the 2025 annual meeting of stockholders must provide notice that sets forth the information required by Rule 14a-19 under the Exchange Act no later than March 15, 2025. [Page 129] How to Reach Our Corporate Secretary Any notice or request that you wish to deliver to our Corporate Secretary should be sent to the following address: Corporate Secretary, ConocoPhillips, P.O. [Page 129] Box 4783, Houston, TX 77210-4783. [Page 129] As required by Article II of our By-Laws, a notice of a proposed nomination must include information about the nominating stockholder(s) and the nominee, as well as a written consent of the proposed nominee to serve if elected. [Page 129] A notice of a proposed item of business must include a description of and the reasons for bringing the proposed business to the meeting, any material interest of the stockholder in the business, and certain other information about the stockholder. [Page 129] You can obtain a copy of ConocoPhillips’ By-Laws by writing the Corporate Secretary or on our website under “Investors > Corporate Governance.” 2024 Proxy Statement 129 [Page 130] Available Information and Q&A About the Annual Meeting and Voting Available Information SEC rules require us to provide an annual report to stockholders who receive this Proxy Statement. [Page 130] Additional printed copies of the Annual Report, as well as our Corporate Governance Guidelines, Code of Business Ethics and Conduct, charters for each of our Board committees, and our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2023, including the financial statements and the financial statement schedules, are available without charge to stockholders upon written request to the ConocoPhillips Shareholder Relations Department, P.O. [Page 130] Box 2197, Houston, Texas 77252-2197 or via our website at www.conocophillips.com. [Page 130] We will furnish the exhibits to our Annual Report upon payment of our copying and mailing expenses. [Page 130] Attending the Annual Meeting Will the Annual Meeting be in person? [Page 130] The 2024 Annual Meeting will be a virtual meeting, conducted exclusively via live audio webcast at www.virtualshareholdermeeting.com/COP2024. [Page 130] There will not be a physical location for the 2024 Annual Meeting, and you will not be able to attend the 2024 Annual Meeting in person. [Page 130] You will be able to attend the Annual Meeting online and be able to vote your shares electronically at the Annual Meeting (other than shares held through our employee benefit plans, which must be voted prior to the meeting). [Page 130] Why is this Meeting Virtual only? [Page 130] The Board believes that holding the Annual Meeting in a virtual format supports an efficient use of company resources and allows stockholders to attend with fewer expenses and logistical issues than an in-person meeting. [Page 130] The Board intends that the virtual meeting format provides a level of transparency as close as possible to the traditional in-person meeting format, and we take the following steps to achieve this: • Providing the opportunity for stockholders to submit questions electronically during the meeting by visiting www.virtualshareholdermeeting.com/COP2024. [Page 130] • Providing the opportunity for stockholders to submit questions in advance of the meeting by visiting www.conocophillips.com/annualmeeting. [Page 130] • Answering questions in accordance with our Meeting Procedures and Rules of Conduct in the time allotted for the meeting without discrimination. [Page 130] • Publishing questions submitted in accordance with our Meeting Procedures and Rules of Conduct along with answers after the meeting, including questions that were not addressed during the meeting. [Page 130] • Providing several meeting opportunities with stockholders as part of our ongoing stockholder engagement to address matters of governance or other appropriate topics (see “Stockholder Engagement in 2023” on page 69). [Page 130] 130 ConocoPhillips 130 [Page 131] Who can attend the Annual Meeting? [Page 131] You are entitled to attend the Annual Meeting only if you were a ConocoPhillips stockholder at the close of business on March 18, 2024, or you hold a valid proxy. [Page 131] You will be able to participate in the Annual Meeting online and submit your questions during the meeting by visiting www.virtualshareholdermeeting.com/COP2024. [Page 131] You also will be able to vote your shares electronically at the Annual Meeting (other than shares held through our employee benefit plans, which must be voted prior to the meeting). [Page 131] To participate in the Annual Meeting, you will need the 16-digit control number included on your Notice of Internet Availability, on your proxy card or on the instructions that accompanied your proxy materials. [Page 131] The Annual Meeting webcast will begin promptly at 9:00 a.m., Central Daylight Time. [Page 131] We encourage you to access the meeting prior to the start time. [Page 131] Online check-in will begin at 8:30 a.m., Central Daylight Time, and you should allow ample time for the check-in procedures. [Page 131] What if during the check-in time or during the meeting I have technical difficulties or trouble accessing the virtual meeting website? [Page 131] We will have technicians ready to assist you with any technical difficulties you may have accessing the virtual meeting. [Page 131] If you encounter any difficulties accessing the virtual meeting during the check-in or meeting time, please call the technical support number that will be posted on the virtual meeting log-in page. [Page 131] What is the Annual Meeting website and how can I access it? [Page 131] All stockholders can visit the Annual Meeting website at www.conocophillips.com/annualmeeting. [Page 131] On our Annual Meeting website, you can vote your proxy, submit questions in advance of the Annual Meeting, view a live webcast of the Annual Meeting, access copies of our Proxy Statement and Annual Report and other information about ConocoPhillips, and elect to view future proxy statements and annual reports online instead of receiving paper copies in the mail. [Page 131] Stockholders of Record and Beneficial Stockholders: Know Which One You Are What is the difference between holding shares as a stockholder of record and as a beneficial stockholder? [Page 131] If your shares are registered directly in your name with Computershare Trust Company, N.A., our registrar and transfer agent, you are considered a stockholder of record with respect to those shares. [Page 131] If your shares are held in a brokerage account or bank, you are considered the “beneficial owner” or “street name” holder of those shares. [Page 131] What is a broker non-vote? [Page 131] Brokers may use their discretion to vote shares held in street name on matters considered “routine” under NYSE rules. [Page 131] Brokers may not vote shares held in street name on non-routine matters unless they have received voting instructions from the beneficial owners. [Page 131] Shares that are not voted on non-routine matters are called broker non-votes. [Page 131] 131 2024 Proxy Statement Available Information and Q&A About the Annual Meeting and Voting [Page 132] Who Can Vote and How Who is entitled to vote? [Page 132] You may vote if you were the record owner of ConocoPhillips common stock as of the close of business on March 18, 2024. [Page 132] Each share of common stock is entitled to one vote. [Page 132] As of March 18, 2024, we had 1,171,101,335 shares of common stock outstanding and entitled to vote. [Page 132] How do I vote? [Page 132] Stockholders of Record: You can vote either using the Internet during the meeting or by proxy. [Page 132] If you vote by proxy, you still are entitled (but not required) to attend the meeting virtually. [Page 132] Even if you plan to attend the meeting virtually, we encourage you to vote your shares in advance. [Page 132] This Proxy Statement, the accompanying proxy card, and our 2024 Annual Report are being made available to stockholders online at www.proxyvote.com. [Page 132] Vote your shares as follows. [Page 132] In all cases, have your proxy card in hand. [Page 132] Beneficial Stockholders: If you hold your ConocoPhillips stock in street name, your ability to vote by telephone or over the Internet depends on your broker’s voting process. [Page 132] Please follow the directions on your proxy card or voting instruction card carefully. [Page 132] Please provide your voting instructions so your vote can be counted on all matters to be considered at the meeting. [Page 132] By Mailing Your Proxy Card If you elected to receive a hard copy of your proxy materials, fill out the enclosed proxy card, date and sign it, and return it in the enclosed postage paid envelope. [Page 132] By Telephone (800) 690-6903 Dial toll-free 24/7 By Internet Using Your Computer Visit 24/7 www.proxyvote.com How do I vote if I hold my stock through ConocoPhillips’ employee benefit plans? [Page 132] If you hold your stock through ConocoPhillips’ employee benefit plans, you must do one of the following: • Vote online (instructions are in the email sent to you or on the notice and access form); • Vote by telephone (instructions are on the notice and access form); or • If you received a hard copy of your proxy materials, fill out the enclosed voting instruction card, date and sign it, and return it in the enclosed postage-paid envelope. [Page 132] You will receive a separate voting instruction card for each employee benefit plan under which you hold stock. [Page 132] Please pay close attention to the deadline for returning your voting instruction card to the plan trustee. [Page 132] Different plans may have different deadlines. [Page 132] What if I am a stockholder of record and return my proxy but do not vote for some of the matters listed on my proxy card? [Page 132] If you return a signed proxy card without indicating your vote, your shares will be voted “FOR” each of the director nominees listed on the card, “FOR” the ratification of Ernst & Young LLP as ConocoPhillips’ independent registered public accounting firm, “FOR” the approval of the compensation of our Named Executive Officers, “FOR” the stockholder proposal on simple majority vote and “AGAINST” the stockholder proposal to Revisit Pay Incentives for GHG Emissions Reductions. [Page 132] 132 ConocoPhillips Available Information and Q&A About the Annual Meeting and Voting

The Board recommends voting against the proposal, arguing that current executive compensation aligns with the company's strategy and stockholder interests.
summarization.main_points: The shareholder proposal highlights that ConocoPhillips' executive pay program includes incentives tied to "Strategic and ESG Milestones," such as demonstrating progress toward a Paris-aligned climate risk framework and emission reduction projects, which the proposal deems unscientific and a breach of fiduciary duty. The company's board, however, believes that the existing executive compensation structure is aligned with the company's strategy, the Triple Mandate (delivering oil and gas, returns on capital, and net-zero operational emissions), and the long-term interests of stockholders. They state an overwhelming majority of stockholders have expressed a desire for the company to link compensation with climate commitments. ConocoPhillips recently added a weighted measure for “Energy Transition Milestones” to its short-term incentive program which had almost universal stockholder support.
summarization.conclusion: The shareholder proposal seeks to change ConocoPhillips' executive compensation structure by removing GHG emission reduction targets, while the Board defends its current approach as being in the best interest of the company and its stockholders, particularly in linking compensation to climate commitments. The Board recommends voting against the proposal with the support of most stockholders.
