[Page 136] 136 ConocoPhillips Available Information and Q&A About the Annual Meeting and Voting [Page 137] Appendix A Non-GAAP Financial Measures Adjusted Earnings Adjusted Earnings is calculated by removing the impact of special items from reported earnings. [Page 137] Special items are items that management believes are unusual or nonrecurring and not indicative of our core operating results or business outlook over the long term. [Page 137] Management believes adjusted earnings is useful to investors in evaluating our operating results, understanding our operating trends across periods on a consistent basis, and providing comparability with the performance of peer companies. [Page 137] Adjusted EPS Adjusted EPS is a measure of the company’s diluted net earnings per share excluding special items. [Page 137] Special items are items that management believes are unusual or nonrecurring and not indicative of our core operating results or business outlook over the long term. [Page 137] Management believes adjusted earnings per share is useful to investors in evaluating our operating results, understanding our operating trends across periods on a consistent basis and providing comparability with the performance of peer companies. [Page 137] Cash from Operations (CFO) Cash from operations (CFO) is calculated by removing the impact from operating working capital from cash provided by operating activities. [Page 137] The company believes that the non-GAAP measure cash from operations is useful to investors to help understand changes in cash provided by operating activities excluding the impact of working capital changes across periods on a consistent basis and with the performance of peer companies in a manner that, when viewed in combination with the company’s results prepared in accordance with GAAP, provides a more complete understanding of the factors and trends affecting the company’s business and performance. [Page 137] Free Cash Flow Free Cash Flow is defined as cash from operations net of capital expenditures and investments. [Page 137] The company believes free cash flow is useful to investors in understanding how existing cash from operations is utilized as a source for sustaining our current capital plan and future development growth. [Page 137] Free cash flow is not a measure of cash available for discretionary expenditures since the company has certain non-discretionary obligations such as debt service that are not deducted from the measure. [Page 137] Return on Capital Employed (ROCE) Return on capital employed (ROCE) is a measure of the profitability of the company’s capital employed in its business operations compared with that of its peers. [Page 137] The company calculates ROCE as a ratio, the numerator of which is net income, and the denominator of which is average total equity plus average total debt. [Page 137] The net income is adjusted for after-tax interest expense, for the purposes of measuring efficiency of debt capital used in operations; net income is also adjusted for non-operational or special items impacts to allow for comparability in the long-term view across periods. [Page 137] The company believes ROCE is a good indicator of long-term company and management performance as it relates to capital efficiency, both absolute and relative to the company’s primary peer group. [Page 5] Third, we accelerated our company’s greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions-intensity reduction target through 2030 and were recognized by the Oil & Gas Methane Partnership 2.0 for our methane reduction efforts. [Page 5] In 2023, we demonstrated meaningful progress toward our Plan for the Net-Zero Energy Transition, including by accelerating our Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions-intensity reduction target from 40-50% to 50-60% gross operated emissions, using a 2016 baseline. [Page 12] • Our non-employee directors meet privately in executive session at each regularly scheduled Board meeting. [Page 12] • Our Board reviews CEO and senior management succession and development plans at least annually and assesses candidates during Board and committee meetings and in less formal settings. [Page 12] • Our Board and committees conduct intensive and thoughtful annual evaluations of the Board, its committees, and its directors, including self-evaluations and peer assessments. [Page 12] See “Board and Committee Evaluations” on page 35. [Page 12] • Our directors provide feedback on Board and committee effectiveness, including areas such as Board composition and the Board/management succession-planning process. [Page 12] The governance best practices we have adopted support these general principles: • Annual election of all directors • Long-standing commitment to sustainability • Stock ownership guidelines for directors and executives • Independent Audit and Finance, Human Resources and Compensation, Public Policy and Sustainability, and Directors’ Affairs committees • Transparent public policy engagement • Prohibition on pledging and hedging for all employees • Proxy access • Active stockholder engagement • Majority independent Board • Executive sessions of non-employee directors held at each regularly scheduled Board meeting • Empowered independent Lead Director • Majority vote standard in uncontested elections • Clawback Policy 12 ConocoPhillips Proxy Summary [Page 13] Executive Compensation Compensation Designed Around our Strategy and Informed by Stockholder Feedback Our executive compensation programs and metrics are aligned with our Triple Mandate and directly tie to our strategic priorities (see page 72). [Page 13] VARIABLE CASH INCENTIVE PROGRAM (VCIP) 14% • One-year performance period - Health Safety & Environment (20%) - Operational (30%) - Financial (30%) - Strategic Milestones (10%) - Energy Transition Milestones (10%) Over 90% of CEO Compensation is Performance Based SALARY 9% • Market competitive; adjusted for experience, responsibility and performance EXECUTIVE RESTRICTED STOCK UNITS 27% • Long-term equity compensation designed to encourage executive retention and aligned with long-term value creation for stockholders (35% of long-term incentive value) - Settles in stock following 3rd anniversary of grant date PERFORMANCE SHARE PROGRAM (PSP) 50% • Performance and equity-based compensation to reward executives for achieving three-year performance targets (65% of long-term incentive value) - Relative Total Shareholder Return (60%) - Financial—Relative Adjusted ROCE (40%) Performance Metrics (VCIP & PSP) are aligned with the Triple Mandate and Company Strategy Each year the HRCC, advised by its independent compensation consultant and informed by feedback from stockholders, undertakes a rigorous process to review our programs. [Page 13] The HRCC believes a substantial portion of our executive compensation should be equity-based and focused on rewarding long-term performance and furthermore, that this approach most closely aligns the interests of our top executives with those of our stockholders (see page 67). [Page 13] Compensation and Governance Practices Through our robust process described under the heading “HRCC Annual Compensation Cycle” on page 78, the HRCC has adopted strong governance practices consistent with the market, some of which are summarized below. [Page 13] WHAT WE DO % Executive compensation aligned with stockholder interests and primarily performance based (see pages 72 & 74) % “Double trigger” vesting after a change in control for long-term incentive awards (see page 94) % Significant stock ownership guidelines (see page 95) % Payouts capped on executive incentive programs % ESG and Human Capital metrics tied to executive and employee compensation (see page 82) % Executives’ incentive compensation subject to clawback policy (see page 95) WHAT WE DON’T DO No excise tax gross-ups for change in control plan participants No current payment of dividend equivalents on unvested long-term incentives for executives No repricing of stock options No pledging, hedging, short sales, or derivative transactions No employment agreements for our named executive officers (“NEOs”) Don’t reward executives for excessive, inappropriate or unnecessary risk-taking 13 2024 Proxy Statement Proxy Summary [Page 14] Progress Report on Our Plan for the Net-Zero Energy Transition Since publishing our Plan for the Net-Zero Energy Transition (our “Plan”), we have continued to focus on implementing our Climate Risk Strategy and advancing the Plan’s objectives. [Page 14] Our commitment to these efforts is demonstrated by our achievements made to date — many of which have been completed ahead of schedule. [Page 14] As we achieve our goals, we fine- tune our strategy and refine our commitments through ongoing engagement with our key stakeholders. [Page 14] The table below provides an update on how we are progressing against our Plan, including demonstrating our progress and achievements in maintaining strategic flexibility, reducing Scope 1 and 2 emissions, addressing Scope 3 emissions and contributing to the energy transition. [Page 14] • Published a new net-zero scenario modeling the collective global government and societal actions that would be required to align with limiting warming to 1.5 degrees. [Page 14] • Invested in LongPath Technologies, a scalable laser-based continuous emissions monitoring solution with the potential to cover targeted assets or provide basin-wide multi-operator coverage. [Page 14] Flaring • On schedule to meet the World Bank Zero Routine Flaring goal by the end of 2025.(1) • Developing total flaring intensity target for 2030. [Page 14] Overall GHG • Accelerated our Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions intensity reduction target through 2030 from 40-50% to 50- 60%, using a 2016 baseline for both gross operated and net equity emissions. [Page 14] • Completed our approved Scope 1 and 2 emissions reductions projects and advanced low carbon opportunities within the allotted capital and cost budget. [Page 14] • Increased our investment in the Climate Asset Management Carbon Fund. [Page 14] • Continued to evaluate a wide range of future offset projects and funds to possibly diversify our portfolio. summarization.introduction: ConocoPhillips demonstrated strong financial and operational performance in 2023, aligning with its value proposition of delivering superior stockholder returns while executing its Triple Mandate. The company focused on responsible energy production, competitive capital returns, and achieving net-zero operational emissions.
summarization.main_points: ConocoPhillips achieved record production levels and enhanced portfolio diversity through acquisitions like the Surmont interest and progressing the Willow project. They delivered competitive returns by distributing $11 billion to stockholders via dividends and share repurchases, and demonstrated commitment to net-zero emissions by accelerating GHG emissions-intensity reduction targets. The company maintained a focus on peer-leading distributions, a strong balance sheet, disciplined investment, and responsible ESG performance, supported by strategic cash flow allocation priorities and robust governance practices including board diversity and stockholder engagement.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips' 2023 performance reflects a commitment to balancing financial success, responsible operations, and environmental stewardship, supported by strong governance and alignment with stockholder interests. The company continues to focus on strategic flexibility and reducing emissions through various initiatives and investments to contribute to the energy transition.

qa_pairs.question: What were ConocoPhillips' full year total and Lower 48 record production in 2023?
qa_pairs.answer: ConocoPhillips' full year total and Lower 48 record production were 1,826 thousand barrels and 1,067 thousand barrels of oil equivalent per day, respectively.

qa_pairs.question: How much did ConocoPhillips distribute to stockholders in 2023, and through what mechanisms?
qa_pairs.answer: ConocoPhillips distributed $11 billion to stockholders through a three-tier framework, including $5.6 billion in cash through the ordinary dividend and variable return of cash (VROC) and $5.4 billion through share repurchases.

qa_pairs.question: What is ConocoPhillips' accelerated GHG emissions-intensity reduction target through 2030?
qa_pairs.answer: ConocoPhillips accelerated its GHG emissions-intensity reduction target through 2030 from 40-50% to 50-60%, using a 2016 baseline.

qa_pairs.question: What are ConocoPhillips' strategic cash flow allocation priorities?
qa_pairs.answer: ConocoPhillips' strategic cash flow allocation priorities are: (1) invest enough capital to sustain production and pay the existing dividend; (2) grow the dividend annually; (3) maintain ‘A’ credit rating; (4) return greater than 30 percent of cash from operations to stockholders; and (5) make disciplined investments to enhance returns.

qa_pairs.question: What designation did ConocoPhillips receive from the Oil & Gas Methane Partnership 2.0?
qa_pairs.answer: ConocoPhillips was awarded the Oil & Gas Methane Partnership 2.0 Gold Standard Pathway designation.

qa_pairs.question: What percentage of the directors are racially or ethnically diverse?
qa_pairs.answer: 33% of the directors are racially or ethnically diverse.

qa_pairs.question: What is the performance share program's focus?
qa_pairs.answer: The performance share program's focus is on performance and equity-based compensation to reward executives for achieving three-year performance targets.

qa_pairs.answer: Methane intensity has been reduced by ~70% since 2015.

chunk_text: [Page 15] ADDRESSING END USE (SCOPE 3) EMISSIONS AND CONTRIBUTING TO THE ENERGY TRANSITION Advocacy and Public Policy • Expanded policy advocacy beyond carbon pricing to include energy efficiency, end-use emissions policy and regulatory action such as direct federal regulation of methane, and national policy recommendations on natural gas across the value chain. [Page 15] • Carbon pricing is the most effective and predictable policy action to reduce GHG emissions across the economy, so ConocoPhillips continues working with World Bank’s Carbon Pricing Leadership Coalition as a private sector partner to share and expand the evidence base for effective carbon pricing in addition to our continued support of the Climate Leadership Council and Americans for Carbon Dividends in the U.S. [Page 15] Supply Chain Engagement • Hosted annual Supplier Sustainability Forum with a focus group of suppliers to identify opportunities to reduce emissions in our value chain. [Page 15] • Collaborated with industry groups and third-party partners to align on collection, reporting and supplier engagement for supplier emissions. [Page 15] LNG • Secured regasification capacity at the Gate LNG terminal in the Netherlands. [Page 15] • Secured 5 MTPA of LNG offtake along with 30% equity in Sempra’s Port Arthur LNG Phase 1 project on the U.S. [Page 15] Gulf Coast which began construction in March. [Page 15] • Signed offtake agreements at Mexico Pacific’s Saguaro LNG and Energia Costa Azul export facility on the west coast of Mexico. [Page 15] CCS & Hydrogen • Continued evaluation of potential opportunities to develop carbon capture and storage (CCS) hubs along the U.S. [Page 15] Gulf Coast. [Page 15] • Participating in Canada’s Oil Sands Pathways Alliance working toward net-zero operational emissions by 2050 through CCS. [Page 15] • Completed an equity investment in Avnos, a hybrid direct air capture innovator, and began evaluating the technology for project development. [Page 15] • Evaluating the development of blue and green ammonia as a low-carbon power generation fuel from the U.S. [Page 15] Gulf Coast with Japanese energy company JERA. [Page 15] We acknowledge the findings of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change that GHG emissions from the use of fossil fuels contribute to increases in global temperatures. [Page 15] We acknowledge the importance that science places on limiting global average temperature increases to below 2-degree Celsius compared to pre-industrial times, and to achieve that, science shows that global GHG emissions need to reach net-zero in the second half of this century. [Page 15] We support the Paris Agreement as a welcomed global policy response to that challenge. [Page 15] We have had a public global climate change position since 2003. [Page 15] The position is reviewed periodically, agreed to by the Executive Leadership Team, and then recommended to the Board. [Page 15] 15 2024 Proxy Statement Progress Report on Our Plan for the Net-Zero Energy Transition [Page 16] Item 1: Election of Directors and Director Biographies What am I Voting On? [Page 16] You are voting on a proposal to elect the 12 nominees named in this Proxy Statement to one-year terms as ConocoPhillips directors. [Page 16] What is the makeup of the Board of Directors and how often are the members elected? [Page 16] Our Board currently has 12 members. [Page 16] Directors are elected at the annual stockholder meeting each year. [Page 16] Any vacancy on the Board created between annual stockholder meetings (if, for example, a current director resigns or the size of the Board is increased) may be filled by a majority vote of the remaining directors then in office. [Page 16] Any director appointed to fill a vacancy would hold office until the next election. [Page 16] Under our Corporate Governance Guidelines, directors generally may not stand for reelection after they reach the age of 72. [Page 16] What if a nominee is unable or unwilling to serve? [Page 16] All director nominees have consented to serve. [Page 16] However, should a director become unable or unwilling to serve before the date of the Annual Meeting and should the Board not elect to reduce the size of the Board, shares represented by proxies may be voted for a substitute nominated by the Board. [Page 16] How are directors compensated? [Page 16] Please see our discussion of director compensation beginning on page 53. [Page 16] How are nominees selected? [Page 16] The Committee on Directors’ Affairs regularly evaluates the size and composition of the Board and continually assesses whether the composition appropriately relates to ConocoPhillips’ strategic needs, which change as the business environment evolves. [Page 16] We seek director candidates who possess the highest personal and professional ethics, integrity, and values and who are committed to representing the long-term interest of all ConocoPhillips’ stakeholders. [Page 16] As some directors approach retirement age, the Committee on Directors’ Affairs seeks to onboard new directors to backfill the needed skills and experience of outgoing directors with sufficient overlap in service to allow for the transfer of institutional knowledge and sharing of experiences. [Page 16] 16 ConocoPhillips [Page 17] The chart below shows our process for identifying and integrating new directors. [Page 17] HOW WE SELECT AND ONBOARD/INTEGRATE NEW BOARD MEMBERS Board assesses its current composition and identifies skills or characteristics needed to enhance its effectiveness, considering things like: • the company’s strategy • current director tenure • established retirement age • results of evaluations Candidates suggested by: • non- employee directors • stockholders • outside search firms • management Pool of candidates vetted based on: • qualifications • leadership experience • integrity, ethics, and judgment • diversity • independence • competing obligations and potential conflicts • mix of skills already on the Board Committee on Directors’ Affairs interviews promising candidates and recommends nominees to the full Board Board nominates candidates for election at next annual meeting or elects new members to serve until stockholders vote at next annual meeting New directors undergo orientation and training Members of the Board provide self- evaluations and evaluations of the full Board and committees Our Corporate Governance Guidelines contain director independence standards consistent with the standards prescribed in the NYSE Listed Company Manual and provide that, at all times, at least a substantial majority of the Board must meet those standards. [Page 17] The Committee on Directors’ Affairs also seeks to ensure that the Board reflects a range of talents, ages, skills, personal attributes, and expertise — particularly in the areas of leadership and management, financial reporting, issues specific to oil- and gas-related industries, both domestic and international markets, public policy and government regulation, technology, public company board service, human capital management, and environmental and sustainability matters — sufficient to provide sound and prudent guidance with respect to ConocoPhillips’ strategic needs. [Page 17] The Board seeks to maintain a diverse membership and also requires that its members be able to dedicate the time and resources necessary to ensure the diligent performance of their duties, including attending Board and applicable committee meetings. [Page 17] To that end, the Committee on Directors’ Affairs considers the number of other boards on which each candidate already serves. [Page 17] Non-employee directors may not serve on more than four other boards of publicly-traded companies in addition to the Board, and ConocoPhillips' Chief Executive Officer may not serve on the board of more than one other publicly-traded company. [Page 17] Directors should seek approval from the Chair of the Board and the Chair of the Committee on Directors’ Affairs in advance of accepting an invitation to serve on another public company board. [Page 18] The chart on the next page shows how these qualifications and skills are distributed among our nominees. [Page 18] CEO OR SENIOR OFFICER FINANCIAL REPORTING INDUSTRY We believe that directors with CEO or senior officer experience provide valuable insights. [Page 18] These individuals have a demonstrated record of leadership and a practical understanding of organizations, processes, strategy, risk and risk management, and the methods to drive change and growth. [Page 18] Through their service as top leaders at other companies, they also bring valuable perspectives on common issues affecting large and complex organizations. [Page 18] We measure operating and strategic performance by reference to financial targets. [Page 18] In addition, accurate financial reporting and robust auditing are critical to ConocoPhillips’ success. [Page 18] Accordingly, we seek to have a number of directors who could qualify as audit committee financial experts (as defined by SEC rules), and we expect all of our directors to be financially knowledgeable. [Page 18] We also believe it is important to have knowledge and experience in capital markets, both debt and equity, given our position as a large publicly traded company. [Page 18] We seek to have directors with significant experience in the energy industry. [Page 18] These directors have valuable perspective on issues specific to our business. [Page 18] GLOBAL REGULATORY/GOVERNMENT TECHNOLOGY As a global energy company, our future success depends, in part, on how we grow our businesses outside the United States. [Page 18] Directors with global business or international experience provide valued perspectives on our operations. [Page 18] The perspectives of directors who have experience within the regulatory field are important. [Page 18] The energy industry is heavily regulated and directly affected by governmental actions and decisions, and we believe that directors with government experience offer valuable insight in this regard. [Page 18] Experience or expertise in information technology helps us pursue and achieve our business objectives. [Page 18] Leadership and understanding of technology, cybersecurity risk, cloud computing, scalable data analytics, and big data technologies add exceptional value to our Board as we increasingly utilize our global data assets to monitor and optimize our operations. [Page 18] PUBLIC COMPANY BOARD SERVICE ENVIRONMENTAL/ SUSTAINABILITY HUMAN CAPITAL MANAGEMENT ConocoPhillips aspires to the highest standards of corporate governance and ethical conduct. [Page 18] Service on the boards and board committees of other large, publicly traded companies provides an understanding of corporate governance practices and trends and insights into: (1) board management; (2) relations between the Board, the CEO, and senior management; (3) agenda setting; and (4) succession planning. [Page 18] We believe this experience supports our goals of strong board and management accountability, transparency, and protection of stockholder interests. [Page 18] Our sustainable development approach is integrated into ConocoPhillips’ planning and decision-making. [Page 18] Directors who have experience with sustainability, including through leadership roles in our industry, strengthen the Board’s oversight and ensure that strategic business essentials and long-term value creation for stockholders are achieved with a responsible, sustainable business model which fosters a stable and healthy environment for tomorrow and proactively addresses stakeholder interests. [Page 18] We could not execute our differential strategy without employees, which is why we value directors with experience in effectively engaging, developing, retaining, and rewarding employees and with experience in diversity, equity, and inclusion management. [Page 20] In a contested election (if the number of nominees exceeded the number of directors to be elected), directors would be elected by a plurality of the shares represented at the meeting and entitled to vote on the election of directors. summarization.introduction: This text covers ConocoPhillips' strategies for addressing end-use emissions, contributing to the energy transition, and electing directors. It details the company's approach to sustainability, governance, and the selection of qualified board members.
summarization.main_points: ConocoPhillips is addressing end-use emissions through advocacy for carbon pricing and energy efficiency policies, along with direct regulation of methane. They are engaging with suppliers to reduce value chain emissions and investing in LNG projects and CCS & Hydrogen technologies, acknowledging the role of fossil fuels in climate change and supporting the Paris Agreement. The document outlines the annual election of ConocoPhillips' 12 directors, detailing the board's makeup, election procedures, and director compensation. The process for identifying, vetting, and integrating new directors is described, emphasizing ethics, diversity, and relevant expertise in areas like leadership, finance, industry knowledge, technology, and sustainability.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips is focused on both reducing its environmental impact through various initiatives and maintaining a strong, diverse, and experienced board of directors to guide the company's strategic direction. The company aims to balance energy production with environmental responsibility and effective corporate governance.

qa_pairs.question: What policy advocacy has ConocoPhillips expanded to include?
qa_pairs.answer: Expanded policy advocacy beyond carbon pricing to include energy efficiency, end-use emissions policy and regulatory action such as direct federal regulation of methane, and national policy recommendations on natural gas across the value chain.

qa_pairs.question: What organization does ConocoPhillips continue to work with as a private sector partner?
qa_pairs.answer: ConocoPhillips continues working with World Bank’s Carbon Pricing Leadership Coalition.

qa_pairs.question: What was the focus of the annual Supplier Sustainability Forum?
qa_pairs.answer: To identify opportunities to reduce emissions in our value chain.

qa_pairs.question: What LNG offtake did ConocoPhillips secure, along with equity?
qa_pairs.answer: Secured 5 MTPA of LNG offtake along with 30% equity in Sempra’s Port Arthur LNG Phase 1 project on the U.S. Gulf Coast.

qa_pairs.question: What agreement has ConocoPhillips signed regarding LNG?
qa_pairs.answer: Signed offtake agreements at Mexico Pacific’s Saguaro LNG and Energia Costa Azul export facility on the west coast of Mexico.

qa_pairs.question: What technology is ConocoPhillips evaluating for project development?
qa_pairs.answer: Evaluating the hybrid direct air capture technology of Avnos.

qa_pairs.question: What is ConocoPhillips evaluating with JERA?
qa_pairs.answer: Evaluating the development of blue and green ammonia as a low-carbon power generation fuel from the U.S. Gulf Coast with Japanese energy company JERA.

qa_pairs.question: What is the timeframe for global GHG emissions to reach net-zero, according to science?
qa_pairs.answer: Global GHG emissions need to reach net-zero in the second half of this century.

qa_pairs.question: When was ConocoPhillips' public global climate change position established?
qa_pairs.answer: Since 2003.

qa_pairs.question: How many directors are on the Board currently?
How long are the terms for the directors being voted on?
qa_pairs.answer: One-year terms

qa_pairs.question: What age is the limit for directors standing for re-election?
qa_pairs.answer: Directors generally may not stand for reelection after they reach the age of 72.

qa_pairs.question: What is the Committee on Directors’ Affairs responsible for?
qa_pairs.answer: Regularly evaluates the size and composition of the Board and continually assesses whether the composition appropriately relates to ConocoPhillips’ strategic needs, which change as the business environment evolves.

qa_pairs.question: What characteristics are sought in director candidates?
qa_pairs.answer: Director candidates who possess the highest personal and professional ethics, integrity, and values and who are committed to representing the long-term interest of all ConocoPhillips’ stakeholders.

qa_pairs.question: How many other boards of publicly-traded companies may non-employee directors serve on?
qa_pairs.answer: Non-employee directors may not serve on more than four other boards of publicly-traded companies in addition to the Board.

qa_pairs.question: How many other boards of publicly-traded companies may ConocoPhillips' Chief Executive Officer serve on?
qa_pairs.answer: ConocoPhillips' Chief Executive Officer may not serve on the board of more than one other publicly-traded company.

qa_pairs.question: What areas of expertise are sought for the board?
qa_pairs.answer: Leadership and management, financial reporting, issues specific to oil- and gas-related industries, both domestic and international markets, public policy and government regulation, technology, public company board service, human capital management, and environmental and sustainability matters.

qa_pairs.question: What kind of skills are helpful to the board?
qa_pairs.answer: Leadership and understanding of technology, cybersecurity risk, cloud computing, scalable data analytics, and big data technologies.

qa_pairs.question: What does experience on other public company boards provide?
qa_pairs.answer: An understanding of corporate governance practices and trends and insights into: (1) board management; (2) relations between the Board, the CEO, and senior management; (3) agenda setting; and (4) succession planning.

qa_pairs.question: What is required to approve the director proposal?
qa_pairs.answer: Each nominee requires the affirmative vote of a majority of the votes cast at the Annual Meeting; the number of votes cast “for” a director must exceed the number of votes cast “against” that director.

qa_pairs.question: What happens if a director nominee does not receive a majority of votes cast?
qa_pairs.answer: The director continues to serve on the Board as a “holdover director” and is required to tender a resignation to the Board.

[Page 32] Prior to his time at Anadarko, he worked in the oil and gas industry, investment and commercial banking, and as an institutional investor. [Page 32] Mr. [Page 32] Walker is currently senior advisor of Jefferies Financial Group Inc. [Page 32] He previously served on the board of directors of BOK Financial Corporation, CenterPoint Energy Corporation, Enable Midstream Partners, LP, and Health Care Services Corporation. [Page 32] Skills and Qualifications: In addition to his former role as Chairman and CEO of Anadarko, Mr. [Page 32] Walker has significant energy industry, commercial and investment banking, and asset management experience, as well as technology, regulatory, governmental, and international business experiences. [Page 32] He has served on and chaired numerous boards of public and private companies, industry trade associations and philanthropic organizations, bringing a broad range of experience and expertise to the Board. [Page 32] CEO or senior officer Financial reporting Industry Global Regulatory/government Technology Public company board service Environmental/sustainability Human capital management FOR The Board recommends you vote FOR each nominee standing for election as director. [Page 32] 32 ConocoPhillips Item 1: Election of Directors and Director Biographies [Page 33] Board Composition and Refreshment We are continuously evaluating the overall balance of the Board, including between longer-tenured directors with great institutional knowledge and new directors with fresh external viewpoints. [Page 33] When considering candidates to fill a vacancy on the Board, the priority is finding a candidate with the necessary skills and qualifications. [Page 33] In addition, we believe the Board benefits from diversity of race, ethnicity, gender, age, education, skills, cultural background, and professional experiences. [Page 33] While our Board consists of diverse members, one of our longstanding female directors recently retired and another longstanding female director resigned to more fully pursue other commitments. [Page 33] These recent departures have resulted in less gender diversity in the Board's current composition, which it is actively seeking to improve. [Page 33] In 2023, the Board undertook a search for qualified female candidates that could bring the right skills and experience to enhance the Board’s composition. [Page 33] A number of candidates have been reviewed and considered, and we are in the process of selecting the right individual, including advanced discussions with one candidate. [Page 33] A great deal of rigor and care is put into the Board refreshment process, which requires time for director selection and onboarding. [Page 33] Nonetheless, we are committed to onboarding at least one new female director by the end of 2024. [Page 33] As part of our Board’s commitment to regular renewal and refreshment: • The Committee on Directors’ Affairs routinely and on an ongoing basis assesses the Board’s composition, taking into consideration any planned retirements for the Board, as well as background and diversity (including gender, ethnicity, race, national origin, and geographic background); • We have implemented an annual Board and Committee assessment process; and • We have adopted Corporate Governance Guidelines that state that directors generally may not stand for re-election after they reach the age of 72. [Page 33] Five of the 12 director nominees have joined the Board in the past 5 years. [Page 33] Almost 42 percent of our director nominees are women or racially/ ethnically diverse individuals. [Page 33] The average age of our director nominees is 63 and the average tenure of our director nominees is 6 years. [Page 33] Board Changes in the Past 5 Years 5 new highly skilled directors have joined our Board 4 directors have left our Board Skills enhanced in the past 5 years CEO or senior officer experience Industry experience ­ Expertise in environmental matters and sustainability Global organization experience 33 2024 Proxy Statement Item 1: Election of Directors and Director Biographies [Page 34] Director Onboarding and Education The Board has an orientation and onboarding program for new directors and provides continuing education for all directors that is overseen by the Committee on Directors’ Affairs. [Page 34] New Director Orientation The orientation program is tailored to the needs of each new director depending on his or her level of experience serving on other boards and knowledge of ConocoPhillips and the oil and gas industry. [Page 34] Materials provided to new directors include information on ConocoPhillips’ strategic plans, financial matters, corporate governance practices, Code of Business Ethics and Conduct, and other key policies and practices. [Page 34] The onboarding process includes a series of meetings with members of senior management and their staff for deep-dive briefings on ConocoPhillips’ operations and financial strategies and SPIRIT Values. [Page 34] In addition, the orientation program includes a visit to ConocoPhillips’ headquarters, and to the extent practicable, certain significant facilities. [Page 34] Continuing Director Education Continuing director education is provided during portions of Board and committee meetings and is focused on topics necessary to assist them in fulfilling their duties, including regular reviews of compliance and corporate governance developments; business-specific learning opportunities through site visits and Board meetings; and briefing sessions on topics that present special risks and opportunities to ConocoPhillips. [Page 34] Education often takes the form of “white papers” covering timely subjects or topics. [Page 34] As part of the Board’s annual evaluation process, directors are asked to identify areas where they feel continuing education would be helpful. [Page 34] Director Education Seminars Directors may attend educational seminars and programs sponsored by external organizations. [Page 34] ConocoPhillips covers the reasonable expenses for a director’s participation in outside continuing education approved by the Committee on Directors’ Affairs. [Page 34] 34 ConocoPhillips Item 1: Election of Directors and Director Biographies [Page 35] Board and Committee Evaluations Each year, the Board performs a rigorous full Board evaluation, and each director performs a self-evaluation and an evaluation of each of his or her peers. [Page 35] Generally, the evaluation process described below is managed by the Corporate Secretary’s office with oversight by the Committee on Directors’ Affairs. [Page 35] However, the Committee on Directors’ Affairs periodically retains an independent third party to manage the evaluation process to ensure it remains as thorough and transparent as possible. [Page 35] 1 EVALUATION QUESTIONNAIRES • Formal opportunity for directors to identify potential improvements • Solicit candid feedback from each director regarding the performance and effectiveness of the Board, its committees, and individual directors 2 INDIVIDUAL INTERVIEWS • Lead Director has an in-depth conversation with each member of the Board 3 REVIEW OF FEEDBACK • Lead Director reviews questionnaire and interview responses with Committee on Directors’ Affairs • Lead Director reviews questionnaire and interview responses with full Board in executive session 4 USE OF FEEDBACK • The Committee on Directors’ Affairs develops recommendations • The Committee on Directors’ Affairs and the Lead Director identify areas for improvement of individual directors and of the Board as a whole • The Committee on Directors’ Affairs uses the results of individual director evaluations as a part of the nomination process for the next annual meeting 5 CHANGES IMPLEMENTED • As a result of this evaluation process, the Board has strengthened its structure and procedures in the following ways over the past few years: – achieved successful transitions of committee leadership roles; – provided more materials as pre-read to improve efficiencies at meetings and allow more time for discussion and deliberation; – more robust committee reports to the full Board; – individual director coaching; and – added new highly skilled directors to enhance the Board’s composition. [Page 35] In addition to participating in the full Board evaluation, members of each committee also complete a detailed questionnaire annually to evaluate how well the committee is operating and to suggest improvements. [Page 35] Each committee’s Chair summarizes the responses and reviews them with the members of his or her respective committee. [Page 35] The Committee on Directors’ Affairs reviews these evaluation processes annually and develops any changes it deems necessary to maintain best practices. [Page 35] 35 2024 Proxy Statement Item 1: Election of Directors and Director Biographies [Page 36] Corporate Governance at ConocoPhillips The Committee on Directors’ Affairs and our Board annually review our governance structure, taking into account any changes in Securities and Exchange Commission (the “SEC”) and New York Stock Exchange (the “NYSE”) rules, as well as current best practices. [Page 36] Our Corporate Governance Guidelines address the matters shown below, among others. [Page 36] • Director qualifications • Director responsibilities • Board committees • Director access to officers, employees, and independent advisors • Director compensation and stock ownership requirements • Director orientation and continuing education • Chief Executive Officer evaluation and management succession planning • Board performance evaluations The Corporate Governance Guidelines are posted on our website under “Investors > Corporate Governance” and are available in print upon request (see “Available Information and Q&A about the Annual Meeting and Voting” beginning on page 130). [Page 36] Board Leadership Structure BOARD OVERVIEW • Chairman and Chief Executive Officer: Ryan M. [Page 36] Lance • Lead Director: Robert A. [Page 36] Niblock • Active engagement by all directors • Ten of our 12 director nominees are independent • All members of the Audit and Finance Committee, Human Resources and Compensation Committee, Public Policy and Sustainability Committee, and Committee on Directors’ Affairs are independent Annual Evaluation of Leadership Structure and Annual Election of Independent Lead Director ConocoPhillips believes that independent board oversight is an essential component of strong corporate performance and enhances stockholder value. [Page 36] The Board believes there is no single organizational model that is the best and most effective in all circumstances. [Page 36] As a result, the Board periodically considers whether the offices of Chairman and CEO should be combined or separated and who should serve in such capacities. [Page 36] Under our Corporate Governance Guidelines, our Board chooses its Chairman based on what is in the best interest of ConocoPhillips and our stockholders. [Page 36] The Chairman and CEO may, but need not, be the same person. [Page 36] As part of its annual review and evaluation process, the Board reviews its leadership structure and whether combining or separating the roles of Chairman and CEO is in the best interest of ConocoPhillips and our stockholders. [Page 36] Our Corporate Governance Guidelines require that, in the event the Board determines that it is in the best interest of ConocoPhillips and its stockholders for the offices of Chairman and CEO to be held by the same person (or in the event the office of Chairman is not held by the CEO, but is nonetheless not independent), an independent lead director must be selected from among the non-employee directors. [Page 36] The Board will continue to reexamine its corporate governance policies and leadership structures on an ongoing basis to ensure that they continue to meet our needs. [Page 36] For the 2023 Proxy Statement, we received a stockholder proposal asking stockholders to vote in favor of requiring the Board of Directors to amend the governing documents, as necessary, to separate the role of CEO and Chairman. [Page 36] After evaluating the proposal, the Committee on Directors’ Affairs determined that it is in the best interest of ConocoPhillips and its stockholders to maintain flexibility in our governing documents to allow the Board of Directors to determine what organizational model best serves the interest of our company and its stockholders. [Page 36] The proposal failed to receive significant support in 2023, with only approximately 25% of stockholders indicating support for the proposal as submitted. [Page 36] During engagements in 2023, stockholders were interested in learning about our leadership structure, and appreciated hearing about how our board has the responsibility to review the governance structure on a regular and ongoing basis, allowing for adaptability. [Page 36] Stockholders expressed support for the Board of Directors continuing to evaluate whether the combined role of Chairman and CEO is in the best interest of the Company. [Page 36] 36 ConocoPhillips [Page 37] Why We Believe in Our Leadership Structure In 2023, the Board reviewed our leadership structure and determined that continuing with a combined Chairman and CEO, with our independent Lead Director, continues to be in the best interest of ConocoPhillips and our stockholders. [Page 37] The Board believes its current structure and processes ensure our Chairman and CEO is in a position to guide the Board in setting priorities for ConocoPhillips and in addressing the risks and challenges we face, while also providing for robust, effective, and independent oversight of management by the Board and our independent Lead Director. [Page 37] Ryan M. [Page 37] Lance Chairman and Chief Executive Officer • Possesses extensive knowledge and deep understanding of the business and challenges we face • Facilitates timely deliberation by the Board of items of the highest priority through his day-to-day insight into our challenges and opportunities • Promotes unity and reliability through consistent leadership direction internally and externally • Serves as a bridge between the Board and management, promoting collaboration while ensuring oversight • Positioned to most effectively execute the strategy for the business to maximize stockholder value • Proven successful in leading ConocoPhillips through business cycles and major transactions, including subsequent integration of acquired businesses Robert A. [Page 37] Niblock Lead Director (Since May 2019) • Extensive experience serving on public company boards provides strong background in corporate governance • Deep understanding of our business and extensive amounts of institutional knowledge having served as an active director since 2010, including rotations on all of the Committees of the Board • Respected by management and the other Directors, promoting a collaborative environment for decision-making, while enabling strong oversight of executive leadership • Strong working relationship with our Chairman and CEO • Deeply invested in ensuring the effectiveness and independence of the Board, holding in-depth conversations with each Director as part of the annual evaluation process The Board consists of ten independent directors. [Page 37] Furthermore, each of the Audit and Finance, Human Resources and Compensation, and Directors’ Affairs committees is made up entirely of independent directors. [Page 37] The Chairs of the Board’s committees establish their agendas and review their committee materials in advance of meetings, conferring with other directors and members of management as each deems appropriate. [Page 37] Moreover, each director is free to suggest agenda items and to raise matters that are not on the agenda at Board and committee meetings. [Page 37] Our Corporate Governance Guidelines require our Lead Director to preside over an executive session of the non-employee directors at every meeting. [Page 37] Each executive session may include a discussion of the performance of the Chairman and CEO, matters concerning the relationship of the Board with the Chairman and CEO and other members of senior management, and such other matters as the non-employee directors deem appropriate. [Page 37] In addition, our Lead Director presides over a meeting of our independent directors at least once a year as required by the NYSE rules. [Page 37] No formal action of the Board is taken at these meetings, although the non-employee directors may subsequently recommend matters for consideration by the full Board. [Page 37] The Board may invite guest attendees for the purpose of making presentations, responding to questions by the directors, or providing counsel on specific matters within their areas of expertise. [Page 37] 37 2024 Proxy Statement Corporate Governance at ConocoPhillips

[Page 38] Board Independence The Corporate Governance Guidelines contain director independence standards that are consistent with the standards set forth in the NYSE Listed Company Manual to assist the Board in determining the independence of ConocoPhillips’ non-employee directors. [Page 38] Under such standards, the Board has determined that all non-employee directors meet the standards regarding independence set forth in the Corporate Governance Guidelines and are free of any material relationship with ConocoPhillips (either directly or indirectly as a partner, stockholder, or officer of an organization that has a relationship with ConocoPhillips). [Page 38] In making such determination, the Board specifically considered the fact that many of our directors may be directors, retired officers, and stockholders of companies with which we conduct business. [Page 38] In addition, some of our directors may serve as employees of, or consultants or advisors to, companies that do business with ConocoPhillips and its affiliates. [Page 38] In all cases, the Board determined that the nature of the business conducted and the interest of the director by virtue of such position were immaterial both to ConocoPhillips and to the director. [Page 38] In recommending that each non-employee director is independent, our Board, with input from the Committee on Directors’ Affairs, considered relationships that, while not constituting related-party transactions in which a director had a direct or indirect material interest, nonetheless involved transactions between ConocoPhillips and a company with which a director is affiliated, whether through employment status or by virtue of serving as a director. [Page 38] Included in the Committee’s review were the following transactions, which occurred in the ordinary course of business. [Page 38] In all instances, it was determined that the nature of the business conducted and the dollar amounts involved were immaterial, both to ConocoPhillips and the relevant counterparty, and fell within independence standards set forth in the ConocoPhillips Corporate Governance Guidelines and the NYSE Listed Company Manual. [Page 38] Seaton Ordinary course business transactions with Boston Consulting Group, The Mosaic Company, and the National Association of Manufacturers 38 ConocoPhillips Corporate Governance at ConocoPhillips [Page 39] Related Party Transactions In accordance with SEC and NYSE rules, we maintain a policy on related party transactions (“Related Party Transaction Policy”), which requires the Audit and Finance Committee to review all Reportable Related Party Transactions in advance. [Page 39] A Reportable Related Party Transaction is a transaction, arrangement, or relationship (or series of similar transactions, arrangements, or relationships) in which: • We (or one of our subsidiaries) was, is or will be a participant; • The aggregate amount involved exceeds $120,000 in any fiscal year; and • Any person who is, or at any time since the beginning of ConocoPhillips’ last fiscal year was, an executive officer, director, director nominee, or holder of at least 5 percent of our equity securities (each a “Covered Person”), or any of such Covered Person’s immediate family members, had, has, or will have a direct or indirect material interest. [Page 39] In accordance with the Related Party Transaction Policy, Covered Persons are required to identify business and financial affiliations involving themselves or their immediate family members that could reasonably be expected to give rise to a Reportable Related Party Transaction. [Page 39] Based on this information, our legal staff, in consultation with the finance team, performs the necessary diligence to determine whether any such Reportable Related Party Transaction exists or will exist, once completed. [Page 39] Upon determining that a transaction is or will be a Reportable Related Party Transaction, the General Counsel presents all relevant facts and circumstances to the Audit and Finance Committee, which reviews transactions for materiality and determines whether the transaction is in the best interest of ConocoPhillips, before either approving or disapproving it. [Page 39] In making its decision, the Audit and Finance Committee considers whether the transaction is on terms comparable to those that could be obtained in arm’s-length dealings with an unrelated third party and the extent of the Covered Person’s interest in the transaction, taking into account the conflicts of interest provisions of ConocoPhillips’ Code of Business Ethics and Conduct and such other factors as it believes are relevant. [Page 39] The Audit and Finance Committee shall prohibit any transactions that it determines are inconsistent with the interests of ConocoPhillips and its stockholders. [Page 39] The Audit and Finance Committee approved the following Reportable Related Party Transactions: Cameron J. [Page 39] Smith, son-in-law of William L. [Page 39] Bullock, Jr., our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, was employed in a non-executive position. [Page 39] The aggregate value of the compensation paid to Mr. [Page 39] Smith during fiscal year 2023 was approximately $346,312, consisting of salary, annual incentive (earned in fiscal 2023 and paid in fiscal 2024), and restricted stock unit awards. [Page 39] In addition, Mr. [Page 39] Smith received the standard benefits provided to other non- executive ConocoPhillips employees for his services during fiscal year 2023. [Page 39] Timothy A. [Page 39] Leach serves as a director and also an employee of the company, but not as an executive officer. [Page 39] Mr. [Page 39] Leach receives compensation from the company for the services he provides as an employee. [Page 39] Mr. [Page 39] Leach does not receive any additional compensation for his service as a director. [Page 41] 41 2024 Proxy Statement Corporate Governance at ConocoPhillips [Page 42] Board Oversight of Risk Management The Board has broad oversight for our risk-management programs. [Page 42] In this role, the Board is responsible for ensuring that the risk-management processes designed and implemented by management are functioning as intended and that necessary steps are taken to foster a culture of prudent decision-making throughout the organization. [Page 42] In order to maintain effective Board oversight across the entire enterprise, the Board delegates to individual committees certain elements of its oversight function, as shown below. [Page 42] In addition, the Board delegates authority to the Audit and Finance Committee to manage the risk oversight efforts of the various committees. [Page 42] As part of this authority, the Audit and Finance Committee regularly discusses ConocoPhillips’ enterprise risk-management policies and facilitates appropriate coordination among committees to ensure that our risk-management programs are functioning properly. [Page 42] The Board receives regular updates from its committees on individual categories of risk, including strategy, reputation, operations, climate change, people, technology, investment, political, legislative, regulatory, and market, and receives a report periodically from the Chair of the Audit and Finance Committee about oversight efforts and coordination. [Page 42] Senior Management ConocoPhillips’ senior management is responsible for day-to-day management of risk, including designing and implementing risk management processes and policies to address the various exposures to risk. [Page 42] Senior management regularly reports to the Board and its committees on a variety of risks. summarization.introduction: This document outlines ConocoPhillips' corporate governance practices, focusing on the responsibilities of the lead director, board independence, related party transactions, board meetings, committee structures, and risk management oversight. It details how the company ensures ethical conduct, transparency, and effective governance.
summarization.main_points: The lead director's responsibilities include presiding over board meetings in the chairman's absence, serving as a liaison, advising on informational needs, and approving agendas and consultant retentions. The Board ensures director independence by adhering to NYSE standards and considering potential conflicts of interest arising from directors' affiliations. The company maintains a Related Party Transaction Policy, requiring Audit and Finance Committee review of transactions exceeding $120,000 involving executive officers, directors, or significant stockholders. The Board has five standing committees (Executive, Audit and Finance, Human Resources and Compensation, Directors’ Affairs, and Public Policy and Sustainability), each with specific responsibilities and independent directors. The Board oversees risk management through its committees, with the Audit and Finance Committee coordinating these efforts, and senior management managing day-to-day risks.
summarization.conclusion: ConocoPhillips demonstrates a commitment to strong corporate governance through defined roles, independent oversight, and comprehensive risk management processes. These practices aim to protect stockholder interests and ensure the company's long-term sustainability.

qa_pairs.question: What are some of the responsibilities of the Lead Director?
qa_pairs.answer: The Lead Director's responsibilities include presiding at Board meetings when the Chairman is absent, serving as a liaison between the Chairman and non-employee directors, advising the Chairman on informational needs of the Board, approving meeting agendas and schedules, calling meetings of non-employee directors, approving consultant retention, ensuring annual Board self-assessments, evaluating the CEO's performance with the HR Committee Chair, and being available for stockholder engagements if requested.

qa_pairs.question: What standards are the director independence standards consistent with?
qa_pairs.answer: The director independence standards are consistent with the standards set forth in the NYSE Listed Company Manual.

qa_pairs.question: What is a Reportable Related Party Transaction?
qa_pairs.answer: A Reportable Related Party Transaction is a transaction, arrangement, or relationship where ConocoPhillips (or a subsidiary) is a participant, the aggregate amount exceeds $120,000 in any fiscal year, and a Covered Person (or their immediate family) has a direct or indirect material interest.

qa_pairs.question: What does the Audit and Finance Committee consider when deciding whether to approve or disapprove a Reportable Related Party Transaction?
qa_pairs.answer: The Audit and Finance Committee considers whether the transaction is on terms comparable to arm’s-length dealings with an unrelated third party and the extent of the Covered Person’s interest in the transaction, taking into account the conflicts of interest provisions of ConocoPhillips’ Code of Business Ethics and Conduct and such other factors as it believes are relevant.

qa_pairs.question: How many times did the Board meet in 2023?
qa_pairs.answer: The Board met five times in 2023.

qa_pairs.question: What are the five standing committees of the Board?
qa_pairs.answer: The Board has five standing committees: (1) the Executive Committee; (2) the Audit and Finance Committee; (3) the Human Resources and Compensation Committee; (4) the Committee on Directors’ Affairs; and (5) the Public Policy and Sustainability Committee.

qa_pairs.question: Which committees conduct an annual self-evaluation?
qa_pairs.answer: Each committee, other than the Executive Committee, conducts an annual self-evaluation.

qa_pairs.question: What are the primary responsibilities of the Human Resources and Compensation Committee?
qa_pairs.answer: The primary responsibilities of the Human Resources and Compensation Committee include overseeing executive compensation policies, plans, programs, and practices, assisting the Board in discharging its responsibilities relating to the fair and competitive compensation of our executives and other key employees, reviewing the performance of the CEO together with the Lead Director, annually reviewing and determining compensation for the CEO and our Senior Officers, reviewing and reporting to the Board annually on the succession-planning process for the CEO and senior management, reviewing and making recommendations to the Board regarding human capital strategies, such as leadership development; cultural; and Diversity, Equity and Inclusion (“DEI”) management, overseeing compliance with SEC rules and regulations regarding stockholder approval of certain executive compensation matters, and assisting the Board in fulfilling its oversight of enterprise risk management, particularly risks in connection with compensation programs and practices and retention strategies.

qa_pairs.question: What is the role of the Audit and Finance Committee in risk management?
qa_pairs.answer: The Audit and Finance Committee manages and coordinates the risk oversight efforts of the various committees and regularly discusses ConocoPhillips’ enterprise risk-management policies.

qa_pairs.question: What areas of risk does the Audit and Finance Committee oversee?
qa_pairs.answer: The Audit and Finance Committee oversees financial/reserve reporting, compliance and ethics, cybersecurity, and litigation and tax matters.
